blockTitle: Installs, Tests and Services Sewers, Sewage Treatment and DWV Systems

questions.taskTitle: Installs, tests and services sewers
questions.subtask: C-8.01 Plans layout and sizes piping for sewers
questions.question: What is the minimum slope required for a 100 mm (4-inch) building sewer?

options.A: 1/8 inch per foot (1%)

explanations.A: 1/8 inch per foot is insufficient for sewer lines and will result in solids deposition and blockages due to inadequate flow velocity.
explanations.B: The minimum slope for a 100 mm (4-inch) building sewer is 1/4 inch per foot (2%) to maintain adequate velocity for solids transport.
explanations.C: 1/2 inch per foot exceeds the minimum requirement and, while acceptable, uses more vertical space than necessary.
explanations.D: 1 inch per foot is excessive for most sewer installations and would consume unnecessary elevation drop.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, tests and services sewers
questions.subtask: C-8.01 Plans layout and sizes piping for sewers
questions.question: When planning sewer layout, what is the primary consideration for determining pipe routing?

options.A: Aesthetic appearance of the installation
options.B: Maintaining minimum slope while avoiding obstacles and ensuring accessibility

explanations.A: While appearance may matter in visible areas, functionality including proper slope and obstacle avoidance is paramount for sewers.
explanations.B: Sewer routing must maintain required slope for gravity flow while avoiding utilities, structures, and providing access for maintenance.
explanations.C: Material selection should be based on specifications and soil conditions, not cost maximization.
explanations.D: Sewer routes should be as direct as practical while meeting slope and access requirements; length itself is not a design goal.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, tests and services sewers
questions.subtask: C-8.01 Plans layout and sizes piping for sewers
questions.question: What factor determines the minimum size of a building sewer?

options.A: The number of fixture units it serves

explanations.A: Building sewer size is determined by the total fixture unit load it must carry, with minimum sizes specified by code.
explanations.B: Building color is unrelated to plumbing load calculations and does not affect sewer sizing requirements.
explanations.C: Building age may influence renovation approaches but does not determine new sewer sizing requirements.
explanations.D: While local codes vary by location, the fundamental sizing determinant is fixture unit load, not location alone.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, tests and services sewers
questions.subtask: C-8.01 Plans layout and sizes piping for sewers
questions.question: What is the minimum diameter for a building sewer according to most plumbing codes?

options.A: 50 mm (2 inches)

explanations.A: 50 mm is too small for building sewers and would be prone to blockages; it does not meet minimum code requirements.
explanations.B: 75 mm is below the code minimum for building sewers and insufficient for typical residential loads.
explanations.C: Most plumbing codes require a minimum 100 mm (4-inch) diameter for building sewers to prevent blockages and ensure adequate capacity.
explanations.D: 150 mm exceeds the minimum requirement and would be oversized for many residential applications.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, tests and services sewers
questions.subtask: C-8.01 Plans layout and sizes piping for sewers
questions.question: When multiple buildings connect to a common sewer, how is the pipe size determined?

options.A: Use the smallest diameter possible
options.B: Cumulative fixture unit load from all connected buildings
options.C: Based on the oldest building only
options.D: All sewers must be 300 mm regardless of load

explanations.A: Using minimum diameter without load calculation would result in undersized sewers prone to backups and failures.
explanations.B: Common sewers must be sized for the total cumulative fixture unit load from all connected buildings plus future provisions.
explanations.C: Building age is irrelevant; sizing must account for total actual and anticipated discharge from all connected structures.
explanations.D: Fixed sizing ignores load requirements; proper design bases size on calculated flow from all connected fixtures.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, tests and services sewers
questions.subtask: C-8.01 Plans layout and sizes piping for sewers
questions.question: What must be considered when planning sewer depth below grade?

options.A: Frost depth, building drain elevation, and maintaining required slope to connection point
options.C: Depth is not important for sewers
options.D: All sewers must be exactly 2 meters deep

explanations.A: Sewer depth must accommodate frost protection, connect to building drains at proper elevation, and maintain slope to municipal connection.
explanations.B: Aesthetics are irrelevant for underground sewers; functional requirements including frost protection and slope determine depth.
explanations.C: Proper depth is critical to prevent freezing, ensure gravity flow, and connect to existing infrastructure at correct elevations.
explanations.D: Fixed depth ignores variable factors like frost line, building drain elevation, and required slope to connection point.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, tests and services sewers
questions.subtask: C-8.01 Plans layout and sizes piping for sewers
questions.question: Why must changes in direction in sewer lines use long-sweep fittings?

options.A: To reduce material costs
options.B: To maintain flow velocity and prevent solids accumulation at direction changes
options.C: To make the system more complex

explanations.A: Long-sweep fittings are typically more expensive than short-radius fittings; cost is not the reason for their use.
explanations.B: Long-sweep fittings maintain flow velocity and reduce turbulence, preventing solids from settling at direction changes.
explanations.C: The purpose is improved hydraulic performance, not complexity; long-sweep fittings simplify flow patterns.
explanations.D: Long-sweep fittings are required by code for drainage and sewer applications to prevent blockages.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, tests and services sewers
questions.subtask: C-8.01 Plans layout and sizes piping for sewers
questions.question: What is the purpose of providing cleanouts in sewer line planning?

options.A: Decorative purposes only
options.B: To allow access for clearing blockages and inspection
options.D: Cleanouts are optional and not needed

explanations.A: Cleanouts are functional components providing maintenance access, not decorative elements.
explanations.B: Cleanouts provide access points for clearing blockages, performing inspections, and maintaining sewer lines.
explanations.C: While cleanouts add cost, their purpose is enabling maintenance access, which prevents more expensive emergency repairs.
explanations.D: Cleanouts are required by code at specified intervals and locations to ensure sewer systems can be maintained.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, tests and services sewers
questions.subtask: C-8.01 Plans layout and sizes piping for sewers
questions.question: At what maximum intervals should cleanouts be provided in straight sewer runs?

options.A: Every 5 meters (16 feet)

explanations.A: 5-meter spacing would be excessively close and impractical for typical sewer installations.
explanations.B: 15 meters is closer than typically required, though more frequent access can be beneficial in problematic areas.
explanations.C: Most codes require cleanouts at maximum 30-meter (100-foot) intervals in straight runs to ensure maintenance accessibility.
explanations.D: 100-meter spacing is too far and would make clearing blockages difficult; codes require more frequent access points.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, tests and services sewers
questions.subtask: C-8.01 Plans layout and sizes piping for sewers
questions.question: When planning connection to a municipal sewer, what must be verified?

options.A: Only the pipe color matches
options.B: Invert elevation, connection method, and permit requirements
options.D: Connection can be made at any elevation

explanations.A: Pipe color is irrelevant; technical factors including elevation, connection specifications, and regulatory compliance are critical.
explanations.B: Municipal connection requires verifying invert elevation for proper slope, approved connection methods, and obtaining necessary permits.
explanations.C: Connection to public infrastructure requires careful verification of technical specifications and regulatory compliance.
explanations.D: Connection elevation is critical to ensure gravity flow; improper elevation can prevent drainage or cause backups.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, tests and services sewers
questions.subtask: C-8.02 Installs maintenance holes and catch basins
questions.question: What is the primary purpose of a sanitary sewer maintenance hole (manhole)?

options.A: To provide access for inspection, cleaning, and maintenance of sewer lines

explanations.A: Maintenance holes provide access for personnel and equipment to inspect, clean, and maintain sewer systems.
explanations.B: Maintenance holes are flow-through structures, not storage facilities; they allow access while sewage passes through.
explanations.C: Sanitary sewers do not require aeration; maintenance holes provide access, not treatment.
explanations.D: Maintenance holes serve critical functional purposes for system access and are not decorative elements.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, tests and services sewers
questions.subtask: C-8.02 Installs maintenance holes and catch basins
questions.question: At what locations are maintenance holes required in sewer systems?

options.A: Only at the property line
options.B: At changes in direction, grade, pipe size, and at maximum spacing intervals
options.D: Only where sewage needs to be stored

explanations.A: Property line locations may require maintenance holes, but they're also needed at other critical points in the system.
explanations.B: Maintenance holes are required at direction changes, grade changes, pipe size transitions, and maximum spacing intervals for access.
explanations.C: Maintenance holes are mandatory at specified locations to ensure system accessibility for maintenance and cleaning.
explanations.D: Maintenance holes provide access, not storage; they're placed at technical transition points and access intervals.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, tests and services sewers
questions.subtask: C-8.02 Installs maintenance holes and catch basins
questions.question: What is the typical minimum internal diameter for a sanitary sewer maintenance hole?

options.A: 300 mm (12 inches)

explanations.A: 300 mm is far too small for personnel access and does not meet minimum code requirements for maintenance holes.
explanations.B: 600 mm is insufficient for safe personnel entry and equipment access in maintenance holes.
explanations.C: Most codes require a minimum 1200 mm (48-inch) internal diameter to allow safe personnel entry and equipment use.
explanations.D: 2400 mm exceeds minimum requirements and would be unnecessarily large and expensive for typical applications.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, tests and services sewers
questions.subtask: C-8.02 Installs maintenance holes and catch basins
questions.question: What is a catch basin used for in drainage systems?

options.A: To catch and separate solids and debris from stormwater before it enters the sewer

explanations.A: Catch basins trap sediment, debris, and pollutants from stormwater runoff before it enters the drainage system.
explanations.B: Catch basins handle stormwater and debris, not potable water; they are drainage system components.
explanations.C: Modern codes typically require separate storm and sanitary sewers; catch basins are for storm drainage separation.
explanations.D: Catch basins are passive sediment traps and do not heat water; they separate solids through gravity settling.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, tests and services sewers
questions.subtask: C-8.02 Installs maintenance holes and catch basins
questions.question: What feature in a catch basin helps trap debris and prevent it from entering the sewer?

options.A: Heating elements
options.B: A sump or sediment trap below the outlet pipe

explanations.A: Catch basins use gravity separation, not heating; they are passive structures relying on settlement.
explanations.B: The sump below the outlet allows debris and sediment to settle, while clearer water flows out the elevated outlet pipe.
explanations.C: Catch basins provide physical separation through gravity, not chemical treatment; they trap sediment mechanically.
explanations.D: Catch basins operate by gravity and do not include pressurization; sediment settles in the sump below the outlet.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, tests and services sewers
questions.subtask: C-8.02 Installs maintenance holes and catch basins
questions.question: How should the base of a maintenance hole be constructed?

options.A: Completely flat throughout
options.B: With channels to direct flow from inlets to outlet maintaining velocity
options.C: With steps to slow down flow
options.D: Rough and uneven to create turbulence

explanations.A: Flat bases allow sewage to pool and solids to settle, creating maintenance problems and flow restrictions.
explanations.B: Benched channels direct flow smoothly through the maintenance hole, maintaining velocity and preventing solids deposition.
explanations.C: Steps would disrupt flow and cause splashing, turbulence, and potential solids accumulation.
explanations.D: Rough surfaces create turbulence and solids accumulation; smooth channels maintain proper flow characteristics.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, tests and services sewers
questions.subtask: C-8.02 Installs maintenance holes and catch basins
questions.question: What must be provided in maintenance holes for safe personnel entry?

options.A: Permanently installed ladders or steps meeting safety standards

explanations.A: Maintenance holes must have secure ladder systems meeting safety codes for safe personnel entry and exit.
explanations.B: Rope alone is insufficient and unsafe; permanent secure ladders or steps are required for reliable safe access.
explanations.C: Safe entry provisions are mandatory for confined space entry in maintenance holes to prevent accidents and enable rescue.
explanations.D: Smooth walls without grip features create fall hazards; proper ladder systems are required for safety.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, tests and services sewers
questions.subtask: C-8.02 Installs maintenance holes and catch basins
questions.question: Why must maintenance hole covers be properly seated and secured?

options.A: For aesthetic reasons only
options.B: To prevent unauthorized access, vehicle damage, and infiltration of surface water
options.D: To allow more water to enter

explanations.A: While appearance matters, the critical reasons are safety, preventing damage from traffic loads, and excluding surface water.
explanations.B: Proper covers prevent accidents, support traffic loads, exclude surface water infiltration, and control access to confined spaces.
explanations.C: Covers are mandatory for safety, load support, and preventing infiltration; they are not optional components.
explanations.D: Proper covers exclude surface water; the goal is preventing infiltration that adds unnecessary load to sewage systems.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, tests and services sewers
questions.subtask: C-8.02 Installs maintenance holes and catch basins
questions.question: What is the purpose of the frame and cover assembly on a maintenance hole?

options.A: To provide a watertight seal, support loads, and allow controlled access

explanations.A: Frame and cover assemblies seal against infiltration, support surface loads including traffic, and provide secure controllable access.
explanations.B: Frame and cover assemblies serve critical structural and functional purposes beyond appearance.
explanations.C: The goal is preventing infiltration, not allowing it; proper covers exclude surface water from the sewer system.
explanations.D: Covers provide controlled access for maintenance, not prevention; they balance security with necessary maintenance accessibility.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, tests and services sewers
questions.subtask: C-8.02 Installs maintenance holes and catch basins
questions.question: How often should catch basins be cleaned to maintain proper function?

options.A: Never, they are self-cleaning
options.B: Regularly, based on sediment accumulation and before sump capacity is compromised

explanations.A: Catch basins accumulate sediment and require periodic cleaning to maintain trapping capacity and prevent outlet blockage.
explanations.B: Regular cleaning based on inspection maintains sediment storage capacity and prevents debris from being carried into the sewer.
explanations.C: Waiting for failure defeats the purpose of catch basins; regular maintenance prevents system problems.
explanations.D: Catch basins typically require annual or more frequent cleaning depending on sediment loading and local conditions.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, tests and services sewers
questions.subtask: C-8.03 Installs piping for sewers
questions.question: What bedding material is typically required under sewer pipe?

options.A: Native soil with rocks and debris
options.B: Graded crushed stone or sand providing uniform support

explanations.A: Native soil with rocks creates point loads that can damage pipe; proper bedding material is required.
explanations.B: Graded granular material provides uniform support, prevents point loads, and allows drainage around the pipe.
explanations.C: Clay retains water and provides poor support; free-draining granular material is specified for pipe bedding.
explanations.D: Proper bedding is essential to support pipe loads and prevent damage; installation without bedding leads to failures.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, tests and services sewers
questions.subtask: C-8.03 Installs piping for sewers
questions.question: What is the minimum depth of bedding material required below sewer pipe?

options.A: No bedding needed below pipe
options.B: Minimum 100-150 mm (4-6 inches) of compacted granular material

explanations.A: Bedding below pipe is essential to provide uniform support and prevent point loading that causes pipe failure.
explanations.B: Typical specifications require 100-150 mm of compacted granular bedding below pipe for proper support and load distribution.
explanations.C: Minimal bedding thickness is insufficient to provide proper load distribution and support required for pipe integrity.
explanations.D: One meter of bedding is excessive and unnecessary; typical requirements are 100-150 mm for proper pipe support.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, tests and services sewers
questions.subtask: C-8.03 Installs piping for sewers
questions.question: Why must sewer pipe joints be properly aligned during installation?

options.A: Alignment is not important for sewers
options.B: To maintain grade, ensure proper gasket seating, and prevent infiltration or blockages

explanations.A: Proper alignment is critical for sewer function; misalignment causes leaks, infiltration, and flow problems.
explanations.B: Alignment maintains design grade for proper flow, ensures gasket seals properly, and prevents joint leaks or offsets that trap solids.
explanations.C: While appearance may be affected in visible areas, the critical reasons are functional performance and preventing failures.
explanations.D: Alignment requirements ensure proper function; they are technical necessities, not arbitrary complications.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, tests and services sewers
questions.subtask: C-8.03 Installs piping for sewers
questions.question: What tool is used to verify proper slope during sewer pipe installation?

options.A: A ruler only
options.B: A laser level, builder's level, or properly set grade stakes

explanations.A: Rulers cannot establish slope over the distances involved in sewer installation; leveling instruments are required.
explanations.B: Laser levels, optical levels, or properly set grade stakes ensure accurate slope throughout the sewer run.
explanations.C: Visual estimation is inadequate for the precision required in sewer grading; proper instruments are necessary.
explanations.D: Slope verification is essential to ensure adequate drainage; improper slope causes flow problems and code violations.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, tests and services sewers
questions.subtask: C-8.03 Installs piping for sewers
questions.question: What precaution must be taken when installing sewer pipe in areas with high groundwater?

options.A: No special precautions needed
options.B: Ensure proper joint sealing, adequate pipe weight or anchoring, and potential flotation prevention

explanations.A: High groundwater creates flotation risk and infiltration potential; specific measures are required to address these concerns.
explanations.B: High groundwater requires watertight joints, weighted or anchored pipe to prevent flotation, and proper backfill for stability.
explanations.C: Thinner walls would reduce strength; high groundwater actually requires adequate strength to resist external pressure.
explanations.D: Proper bedding is even more critical in wet conditions to provide stable support and prevent settlement.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, tests and services sewers
questions.subtask: C-8.03 Installs piping for sewers
questions.question: How should sewer pipe be stored on site before installation?

options.A: Thrown in a pile without support
options.B: On level ground with proper support to prevent deformation
options.D: In direct sunlight for extended periods

explanations.A: Improper storage causes pipe deformation, gasket damage, and contamination of joints and interiors.
explanations.B: Pipe should be stored on level supports to prevent deformation, with protection from contamination and UV exposure.
explanations.C: Vertical storage of long pipe sections creates instability and potential for falling and damage.
explanations.D: Extended UV exposure degrades plastic pipe; storage should protect materials from weathering and contamination.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, tests and services sewers
questions.subtask: C-8.03 Installs piping for sewers
questions.question: What must be done if sewer pipe installation is interrupted overnight or for extended periods?

options.A: Leave open ends completely unprotected
options.B: Plug or cap all open ends to prevent debris entry and animal intrusion

explanations.A: Open ends allow debris, animals, and water to enter, contaminating the system and potentially causing blockages.
explanations.B: Temporary plugs or caps prevent contamination, debris entry, and animal intrusion during construction delays.
explanations.C: Filling with water does not prevent debris entry and could cause stability issues or freezing problems.
explanations.D: Leaving open ends unprotected allows contamination and debris that must be removed before completing installation.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, tests and services sewers
questions.subtask: C-8.03 Installs piping for sewers
questions.question: When connecting to an existing sewer, what must be verified before cutting into the line?

options.A: Flow patterns, existing line condition, and proper isolation or bypass arrangements

explanations.A: Connecting to active sewers requires understanding flow conditions, verifying line integrity, and arranging for flow control during connection.
explanations.B: Pipe identification is one factor, but flow conditions, structural integrity, and isolation plans are critical for safe connections.
explanations.C: Cutting into active sewers without proper planning creates hazardous conditions and service disruptions.
explanations.D: While weather affects work conditions, the critical factors are flow management and proper connection procedures.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, tests and services sewers
questions.subtask: C-8.03 Installs piping for sewers
questions.question: What is the purpose of initial backfill material around sewer pipe?

options.A: To immediately crush the pipe
options.B: To provide lateral support while protecting pipe from damage during subsequent backfilling
options.D: To create voids around the pipe

explanations.A: Initial backfill protects pipe, not crushes it; proper material and placement provide support without damage.
explanations.B: Initial backfill of select material provides lateral pipe support and cushioning before placing and compacting final backfill.
explanations.C: Initial backfill is critical for pipe protection and support before full trench backfilling can proceed safely.
explanations.D: Initial backfill should be well-compacted around pipe to provide support; voids would allow pipe movement and damage.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, tests and services sewers
questions.subtask: C-8.03 Installs piping for sewers
questions.question: Why must sewer trenches be kept dewatered during pipe installation?

options.A: Water improves pipe installation
options.B: To provide stable working conditions, prevent pipe flotation, and enable proper bedding compaction

explanations.A: Water in trenches creates unstable conditions, flotation risk, and prevents proper bedding and backfill compaction.
explanations.B: Dewatering provides safe working conditions, prevents pipe flotation, and allows proper bedding and backfill placement.
explanations.C: Dewatering is often essential for safety, pipe stability, and achieving proper installation in areas with groundwater.
explanations.D: Wet conditions are problematic; dewatering creates proper conditions for stable, code-compliant installation.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, tests and services sewers
questions.subtask: C-8.04 Tests maintenance holes, catch basins and piping for sewers
questions.question: What is the primary purpose of testing sewer systems after installation?

options.A: Testing is optional
options.B: To verify system is watertight, properly graded, and free of defects before burial and acceptance

explanations.A: Testing is mandatory to verify system integrity before covering; it prevents costly future repairs and environmental damage.
explanations.B: Testing confirms the system is watertight, properly sloped, defect-free, and ready for service before burial.
explanations.C: Testing serves critical functional purposes verifying system integrity, not aesthetic concerns.
explanations.D: Testing is a necessary quality assurance step that prevents failures, not an arbitrary delay.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, tests and services sewers
questions.subtask: C-8.04 Tests maintenance holes, catch basins and piping for sewers
questions.question: What test is commonly used to verify sewer pipe watertightness?

options.A: Visual inspection only
options.B: Hydrostatic pressure test or low-pressure air test

explanations.A: Visual inspection cannot detect all leaks; pressure testing is required to verify joint integrity throughout the system.
explanations.B: Hydrostatic or low-pressure air testing pressurizes the system to reveal leaks before burial and acceptance.
explanations.C: Hammer testing is for different purposes; pressure testing is the standard method for verifying sewer watertightness.
explanations.D: Formal testing is required by codes to verify sewer integrity before burial and acceptance.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, tests and services sewers
questions.subtask: C-8.04 Tests maintenance holes, catch basins and piping for sewers
questions.question: How is a hydrostatic test performed on a sewer line?

options.A: By visual inspection only
options.B: Fill line with water to specified head, plug ends, and monitor for pressure loss indicating leaks

explanations.A: Visual inspection alone cannot verify watertightness under pressure conditions; actual pressure testing is required.
explanations.B: Hydrostatic testing fills the line with water under pressure and monitors for level or pressure drops indicating leaks.
explanations.C: While leaks may produce sounds, quantitative pressure monitoring is the reliable method for detecting all leaks.
explanations.D: Hydrostatic testing is a standard and widely used method for verifying sewer pipe integrity.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, tests and services sewers
questions.subtask: C-8.04 Tests maintenance holes, catch basins and piping for sewers
questions.question: What test pressure is typically used for low-pressure air testing of sewers?

options.A: 14 kPa (2 psi)
options.C: 3.5 to 4 kPa (0.5 psi) above groundwater pressure

explanations.A: 14 kPa is too high for low-pressure air testing and could damage joints or pipe.
explanations.B: 100 kPa far exceeds low-pressure air test specifications and would be dangerous for gravity sewer testing.
explanations.C: Low-pressure air testing typically uses 3.5-4 kPa above groundwater pressure to safely detect leaks without damage.
explanations.D: 700 kPa is extremely excessive and dangerous; low-pressure air tests use only a few kPa above ambient.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, tests and services sewers
questions.subtask: C-8.04 Tests maintenance holes, catch basins and piping for sewers
questions.question: Why are maintenance holes tested separately or given special attention during system testing?

options.A: They don't need testing
options.B: Maintenance holes have multiple joints and connections making them potential leak points
options.D: They are always leak-free by design

explanations.A: Maintenance holes require thorough testing as they represent complex connections with multiple potential leak paths.
explanations.B: Multiple pipe connections, base joints, and wall penetrations make maintenance holes critical testing focus points.
explanations.C: Maintenance hole testing is possible and necessary using appropriate methods including water level monitoring or pressure decay.
explanations.D: Despite careful construction, maintenance holes must be tested as joints and connections can develop leaks.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, tests and services sewers
questions.subtask: C-8.04 Tests maintenance holes, catch basins and piping for sewers
questions.question: What is the purpose of infiltration testing for sewers?

options.A: To measure how much groundwater leaks into the sewer system
options.B: To increase water in the sewer

explanations.A: Infiltration testing measures groundwater entering the sewer, which adds unnecessary load to treatment facilities and indicates leaks.
explanations.B: The purpose is detecting and quantifying unwanted infiltration, not intentionally adding water to the system.
explanations.C: Infiltration testing is an important verification that sewers are not allowing groundwater entry through leaks.
explanations.D: Sewers handle wastewater, not drinking water; infiltration testing measures groundwater entry into sewers.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, tests and services sewers
questions.subtask: C-8.04 Tests maintenance holes, catch basins and piping for sewers
questions.question: What must be done if leaks are discovered during sewer testing?

options.A: Ignore them and proceed
options.B: Locate leaks, repair defects, and retest until system passes
options.D: Testing is complete even with leaks

explanations.A: Leaks must be repaired before acceptance; ignoring them leads to groundwater infiltration and environmental contamination.
explanations.B: Failed tests require identifying leak locations, making repairs, and retesting until the system meets acceptance criteria.
explanations.C: Covering defects without repair creates long-term problems with infiltration, exfiltration, and potential environmental damage.
explanations.D: Systems must pass testing before acceptance; leaks indicate defects requiring correction before burial.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, tests and services sewers
questions.subtask: C-8.04 Tests maintenance holes, catch basins and piping for sewers
questions.question: How is lamping used in sewer inspection?

options.A: To provide heat to the sewer
options.B: Shining light through pipe from one maintenance hole to visually inspect for blockages or misalignment
options.C: Lamping is not used in sewers

explanations.A: Lamping is an inspection technique using light for visualization, not a heating method.
explanations.B: Lamping involves shining a strong light through the pipe to visually detect blockages, debris, or alignment problems.
explanations.C: Lamping is a simple, traditional method still used for basic visual inspection of sewer line continuity.
explanations.D: Lamping is a professional inspection technique for detecting obstructions and alignment issues in sewers.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, tests and services sewers
questions.subtask: C-8.04 Tests maintenance holes, catch basins and piping for sewers
questions.question: What documentation should be maintained for sewer testing?

options.A: No documentation needed
options.B: Test date, method, results, defects found, repairs made, and final acceptance

explanations.A: Comprehensive documentation is required for code compliance, warranty, and future reference.
explanations.B: Complete test records document compliance, provide warranty evidence, and create maintenance reference information.
explanations.C: Contractor identification is one small part; complete technical test data and results must be documented.
explanations.D: Documentation is mandatory for proving code compliance and providing records for future maintenance and warranty claims.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, tests and services sewers
questions.subtask: C-8.05 Services maintenance holes, catch basins and piping for sewers
questions.question: What is the primary method for clearing blocked sewer lines?

options.A: Using mechanical augers/snakes or high-pressure water jetting

explanations.A: Mechanical augering and high-pressure jetting are safe, effective methods for clearing sewer blockages.
explanations.B: Explosives would damage piping and create dangerous conditions; mechanical methods are appropriate.
explanations.C: Blockages must be cleared to restore function; ignoring them causes backups and potential property damage.
explanations.D: While chemicals may help in some situations, mechanical clearing is more effective and doesn't risk pipe damage from harsh chemicals.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, tests and services sewers
questions.subtask: C-8.05 Services maintenance holes, catch basins and piping for sewers
questions.question: Why should catch basins be inspected and cleaned regularly?

options.A: To maintain sediment storage capacity and prevent system blockages

explanations.A: Regular cleaning maintains trap capacity, prevents sediment from entering sewers, and ensures proper stormwater management.
explanations.B: Catch basins accumulate sediment continuously and require regular cleaning to maintain function.
explanations.C: Catch basins are functional components requiring maintenance for performance, not aesthetic reasons.
explanations.D: Regular inspection prevents system failures and is cost-effective compared to emergency repairs and system damage.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, tests and services sewers
questions.subtask: C-8.05 Services maintenance holes, catch basins and piping for sewers
questions.question: What safety precautions are essential when entering maintenance holes?

options.A: No precautions needed
options.B: Atmospheric testing, ventilation, confined space training, proper PPE, and standby personnel

explanations.A: Maintenance holes are confined spaces with serious hazards requiring comprehensive safety protocols.
explanations.B: Safe entry requires gas testing, forced ventilation, trained personnel, appropriate PPE, and rescue-ready standby staff.
explanations.C: Quick entry without precautions is extremely dangerous due to toxic gases, oxygen deficiency, and other confined space hazards.
explanations.D: Maintenance holes require periodic entry for inspection and maintenance; proper safety procedures enable safe access.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, tests and services sewers
questions.subtask: C-8.05 Services maintenance holes, catch basins and piping for sewers
questions.question: What hazard makes sewers and maintenance holes particularly dangerous?

options.A: Cold temperatures only
options.B: Presence of toxic gases including hydrogen sulfide, methane, and potential oxygen deficiency

explanations.A: While temperature can be a concern, toxic and explosive gases pose the primary life-threatening hazards in sewers.
explanations.B: Sewers generate hydrogen sulfide, methane, and carbon dioxide, creating toxic, explosive, and oxygen-deficient atmospheres.
explanations.C: Sewers and maintenance holes are hazardous confined spaces requiring rigorous safety protocols for safe entry.
explanations.D: Insufficient lighting is actually a concern; the primary hazards are atmospheric dangers from toxic and explosive gases.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, tests and services sewers
questions.subtask: C-8.05 Services maintenance holes, catch basins and piping for sewers
questions.question: How can root intrusion in sewer lines be addressed?

options.A: Ignore it completely
options.B: Mechanical cutting followed by repair or replacement of damaged sections and root-resistant measures
options.C: Add more roots to the system

explanations.A: Root intrusion causes blockages and pipe damage requiring prompt attention to prevent system failure.
explanations.B: Removing roots mechanically, repairing damaged pipe, and implementing preventive measures addresses root intrusion effectively.
explanations.C: Roots cause blockages and damage; the goal is removal and prevention, not adding more vegetation.
explanations.D: Root intrusion can be addressed through mechanical removal, pipe repair, and preventive chemical or physical barriers.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, tests and services sewers
questions.subtask: C-8.05 Services maintenance holes, catch basins and piping for sewers
questions.question: What is CCTV inspection used for in sewer maintenance?

options.A: Entertainment purposes
options.B: Visual inspection of pipe interior condition to identify cracks, blockages, and defects
options.C: CCTV is never used in sewers

explanations.A: CCTV inspection is a professional diagnostic tool for assessing sewer condition, not entertainment.
explanations.B: CCTV cameras remotely inspect pipe interiors, documenting condition, identifying problems, and planning repairs without excavation.
explanations.C: CCTV inspection is a widely used, cost-effective method for sewer assessment and condition monitoring.
explanations.D: CCTV inspection uses specialized equipment to document pipe condition for maintenance planning, not entertainment viewing.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, tests and services sewers
questions.subtask: C-8.05 Services maintenance holes, catch basins and piping for sewers
questions.question: What maintenance should be performed on maintenance hole frames and covers?

options.A: No maintenance needed
options.B: Regular inspection, cleaning, lubrication of locking mechanisms, and ensuring proper seating

explanations.A: Covers and frames require maintenance to ensure they seat properly, exclude infiltration, and remain accessible.
explanations.B: Regular maintenance ensures covers seat properly, open when needed, exclude water, and remain safe for traffic loads.
explanations.C: Welding covers shut prevents necessary access for inspection and maintenance; covers must remain removable.
explanations.D: Removing covers creates safety hazards and allows infiltration; covers must be maintained in place and functional.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, tests and services sewers
questions.subtask: C-8.05 Services maintenance holes, catch basins and piping for sewers
questions.question: How can grease accumulation in sewers be prevented or managed?

options.A: Add more grease to dilute it
options.B: Grease traps at sources, regular cleaning, and public education on proper disposal

explanations.A: Adding grease worsens the problem; the goal is preventing grease from entering sewers.
explanations.B: Grease traps capture fats before sewer entry, regular cleaning removes accumulation, and education prevents introduction.
explanations.C: Grease solidifies in sewers causing blockages and is a major maintenance problem requiring prevention and removal.
explanations.D: Grease management is achievable through source control, trapping, regular cleaning, and proper disposal practices.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, tests and services sewers
questions.subtask: C-8.05 Services maintenance holes, catch basins and piping for sewers
questions.question: What is the purpose of smoke testing in sewer systems?

options.A: To add fragrance to sewers
options.B: To identify illegal connections, cross-connections, and infiltration points

explanations.A: Smoke testing is a diagnostic technique for finding defects, not an odor control method.
explanations.B: Non-toxic smoke introduced into sewers reveals leaks, illegal connections, and defects where smoke escapes.
explanations.C: Smoke testing is a valuable diagnostic tool for identifying sewer system defects and improper connections.
explanations.D: Smoke is used for leak detection and tracing connections, not for heating purposes in sewer systems.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, tests and services sewage treatment systems
questions.subtask: C-9.01 Plans installation of sewage treatment systems
questions.question: What factors must be considered when selecting a sewage treatment system for a property?

options.A: Soil conditions, site size, water table, percolation rate, and local regulations

explanations.A: Site assessment including soil, space, hydrology, and regulatory requirements determines appropriate treatment system type and design.
explanations.B: While cost is a factor, technical site characteristics and code compliance determine feasibility and appropriate system selection.
explanations.C: House appearance is unrelated to subsurface sewage treatment system design and selection.
explanations.D: Multiple technical and regulatory factors must be evaluated to select and design an appropriate sewage treatment system.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, tests and services sewage treatment systems
questions.subtask: C-9.01 Plans installation of sewage treatment systems
questions.question: What is a percolation test used for in sewage system planning?

options.A: To test drinking water quality
options.B: To determine soil absorption rate for sizing drainage fields

explanations.A: Percolation tests assess soil drainage characteristics, not water quality; they determine absorption field sizing.
explanations.B: Percolation tests measure how quickly water drains through soil, determining absorption area requirements for treatment systems.
explanations.C: Percolation testing measures soil drainage rates, not atmospheric conditions like temperature.
explanations.D: Percolation testing is a standard requirement for designing and sizing soil-based sewage treatment absorption areas.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, tests and services sewage treatment systems
questions.subtask: C-9.01 Plans installation of sewage treatment systems
questions.question: What is the purpose of a septic tank in an on-site sewage treatment system?

options.A: To provide complete sewage treatment
options.B: Primary treatment through settling and anaerobic digestion, separating solids from liquid

explanations.A: Septic tanks provide preliminary treatment; additional treatment occurs in absorption fields or advanced systems.
explanations.B: Septic tanks allow solids to settle and undergo partial digestion while clarified liquid flows to absorption areas for final treatment.
explanations.C: Septic tanks are passive treatment units relying on biological processes, not heating systems.
explanations.D: Septic tanks perform critical primary treatment, protecting absorption fields from solids and providing partial treatment.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, tests and services sewage treatment systems
questions.subtask: C-9.01 Plans installation of sewage treatment systems
questions.question: What minimum distance is typically required between a septic system absorption field and a water well?

options.A: 1 meter (3 feet)
options.C: 15 meters (50 feet) or more depending on local codes

explanations.A: 1 meter is grossly insufficient to protect wells from sewage contamination; much greater separation is required.
explanations.B: 5 meters is inadequate separation for preventing well contamination from sewage; codes require much greater distances.
explanations.C: Most codes require minimum 15-meter separation, with greater distances for upgradient wells or adverse soil conditions.
explanations.D: Separation is critical to prevent sewage contamination of drinking water; substantial distances are mandated by health codes.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, tests and services sewage treatment systems
questions.subtask: C-9.01 Plans installation of sewage treatment systems
questions.question: Why must absorption fields be located in suitable soil with adequate drainage?

options.A: For appearance only
options.B: Proper drainage allows effluent infiltration and treatment while preventing system failure

explanations.A: Soil suitability is critical for system function and environmental protection, not appearance.
explanations.B: Well-drained soil allows effluent infiltration for final treatment and disposal while preventing surfacing or system saturation.
explanations.C: Drainage is essential for system function; poor drainage causes failure, surfacing sewage, and environmental contamination.
explanations.D: The goal is infiltration and treatment, not creating wet conditions; saturated soil indicates system failure.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, tests and services sewage treatment systems
questions.subtask: C-9.01 Plans installation of sewage treatment systems
questions.question: What is the purpose of a distribution box in a septic system?

options.A: To store sewage
options.B: To evenly distribute effluent to multiple absorption field lines

explanations.A: Distribution boxes do not store sewage; they divide flow among absorption lines for even loading.
explanations.B: Distribution boxes divide septic tank effluent equally among multiple absorption trenches or beds for efficient treatment.
explanations.C: Distribution boxes are passive flow dividers and do not heat effluent; temperature is not controlled.
explanations.D: Distribution boxes are standard components ensuring even flow distribution in multi-line absorption fields.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, tests and services sewage treatment systems
questions.subtask: C-9.01 Plans installation of sewage treatment systems
questions.question: What sizing factor determines septic tank capacity?

options.A: Number of bedrooms and daily water usage
options.C: All tanks are the same size

explanations.A: Septic tank sizing is based on occupancy (typically bedroom count) and daily water usage to provide adequate retention time.
explanations.B: House appearance is unrelated to sewage generation and has no bearing on septic tank sizing requirements.
explanations.C: Tank size must match occupancy and flow; one size does not suit all applications and would cause failures.
explanations.D: Tank sizing follows engineering criteria based on flow and occupancy; random selection would result in undersized or oversized systems.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, tests and services sewage treatment systems
questions.subtask: C-9.01 Plans installation of sewage treatment systems
questions.question: Why should septic systems be located away from property lines and buildings?

options.A: Setback requirements protect neighboring properties and allow access for maintenance

explanations.A: Setbacks prevent contamination of adjacent properties, protect structures, and ensure access for repairs and pumping.
explanations.B: Setbacks are mandated by codes to protect health, property values, and enable system maintenance.
explanations.C: While appearance may be affected, the critical reasons are health protection, property protection, and maintenance access.
explanations.D: Setbacks serve important health and maintenance purposes; they are not arbitrary space requirements.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, tests and services sewage treatment systems
questions.subtask: C-9.01 Plans installation of sewage treatment systems
questions.question: What role does the health department play in sewage system planning?

options.A: No role in sewage planning
options.B: Reviews plans, issues permits, inspects installations to protect public health

explanations.A: Health departments have primary regulatory authority over sewage systems due to public health implications.
explanations.B: Health authorities review designs, approve permits, and inspect installations to ensure systems protect public health and environment.
explanations.C: Health departments focus on public health protection through proper sewage treatment, not aesthetic concerns.
explanations.D: Sewage treatment is a primary public health concern; health departments actively regulate and oversee these systems.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, tests and services sewage treatment systems
questions.subtask: C-9.01 Plans installation of sewage treatment systems
questions.question: What is an aerobic treatment unit (ATU)?

options.A: A type of septic tank without oxygen
options.B: Advanced system using forced aeration to achieve higher treatment levels than conventional septic tanks
options.C: ATUs are not used in sewage treatment

explanations.A: ATUs specifically introduce oxygen; they differ from conventional septic tanks by using aerobic rather than anaerobic processes.
explanations.B: ATUs mechanically inject air to support aerobic bacteria, achieving better treatment than conventional septic tanks.
explanations.C: ATUs are alternative treatment systems used where enhanced treatment is needed or soil conditions limit conventional systems.
explanations.D: ATUs are sewage treatment devices using biological processes with aeration, not water heating equipment.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, tests and services sewage treatment systems
questions.subtask: C-9.02 Installs components for sewage treatment systems
questions.question: What must be verified before placing a septic tank in an excavation?

options.A: Excavation depth, level base, and adequate clearance for connections

explanations.A: Proper depth, level stable base, and clearance for piping ensure correct installation and long-term stability.
explanations.B: Simply having an excavation is insufficient; depth, levelness, and base preparation are critical for proper installation.
explanations.C: While soil type matters for bearing, the critical factors are excavation dimensions, levelness, and base preparation.
explanations.D: Verification prevents improper installation that could cause tank settlement, connection problems, or system failure.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, tests and services sewage treatment systems
questions.subtask: C-9.02 Installs components for sewage treatment systems
questions.question: Why must septic tanks be installed level?

options.A: Level installation is optional
options.B: To ensure proper liquid level operation, sludge storage, and effluent outlet function

explanations.A: Level installation is essential for proper tank function; unlevel tanks malfunction and cause premature failures.
explanations.B: Level tanks maintain proper liquid levels, maximize sludge storage, and ensure effluent outlet functions at design elevation.
explanations.C: While level installation looks better, the critical reasons are functional performance and proper liquid level maintenance.
explanations.D: Tilted tanks disrupt settling, reduce effective capacity, and cause outlet dysfunction; level installation is required.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, tests and services sewage treatment systems
questions.subtask: C-9.02 Installs components for sewage treatment systems
questions.question: What material is commonly used for modern absorption field trenches?

options.A: Washed gravel or crushed stone with distribution piping

explanations.A: Clean gravel or stone provides void space for effluent storage and distribution while allowing infiltration to surrounding soil.
explanations.B: Clay soil is impermeable and unsuitable for absorption trenches; it would prevent infiltration and cause system failure.
explanations.C: Concrete blocks provide no infiltration capacity; proper absorption requires permeable media like gravel.
explanations.D: While sand can be used in certain systems, washed gravel is the standard media providing proper void space and infiltration.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, tests and services sewage treatment systems
questions.subtask: C-9.02 Installs components for sewage treatment systems
questions.question: Why is geotextile fabric placed over absorption trenches?

options.A: To prevent soil migration into gravel while allowing water movement

explanations.A: Geotextile filters prevent soil from filling voids in gravel while allowing water to infiltrate for treatment.
explanations.B: The goal is preventing soil intrusion while maintaining infiltration; complete water blockage would cause system failure.
explanations.C: Geotextile fabric is standard for protecting absorption trench integrity and is required by most modern codes.
explanations.D: Fabric serves critical filtration functions preventing soil migration; it is not a decorative element.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, tests and services sewage treatment systems
questions.subtask: C-9.02 Installs components for sewage treatment systems
questions.question: What is the purpose of the riser and access cover on a septic tank?

options.A: To provide ground-level access for inspection and pumping

explanations.A: Risers bring access to grade level, facilitating inspection, pumping, and maintenance without excavation.
explanations.B: While appearance is a consideration, the primary purpose is providing necessary access for routine maintenance.
explanations.C: Risers and covers seal the tank; they provide maintenance access, not overflow provisions.
explanations.D: Regular access is essential for required pumping and inspection; risers eliminate excavation for routine maintenance.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, tests and services sewage treatment systems
questions.subtask: C-9.02 Installs components for sewage treatment systems
questions.question: How should absorption field trenches be oriented relative to slope?

options.A: Following the slope downhill
options.B: Across the slope on contour for even distribution

explanations.A: Running downslope causes effluent to flow to the lowest point, preventing even distribution and causing localized overload.
explanations.B: Trenches on contour distribute effluent evenly along their length, preventing concentration and maximizing treatment area.
explanations.C: Orientation is critical for even distribution; improper orientation causes localized failure and inefficient treatment area use.
explanations.D: Vertical trenches are impractical and would not provide proper distribution or infiltration area.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, tests and services sewage treatment systems
questions.subtask: C-9.02 Installs components for sewage treatment systems
questions.question: What must be checked before backfilling over absorption field components?

options.A: Proper installation, correct materials, level distribution, and inspection approval

explanations.A: Verification before burial ensures proper installation; corrections after backfilling are extremely costly and disruptive.
explanations.B: Inspection before backfilling is essential; buried defects are difficult and expensive to correct.
explanations.C: While weather affects backfilling conditions, the critical factors are proper installation and passing inspection.
explanations.D: Backfilling before inspection prevents verification and may bury defects requiring costly excavation to correct.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, tests and services sewage treatment systems
questions.subtask: C-9.02 Installs components for sewage treatment systems
questions.question: Why must septic tank baffles or tees be properly positioned?

options.A: Baffles are not important
options.B: To direct flow, prevent scum discharge, and protect the outlet

explanations.A: Baffles are critical for proper tank function; they prevent solids from escaping and protect the absorption field.
explanations.B: Properly positioned baffles direct flow through the tank, keep floating scum and settled solids from exiting to the absorption field.
explanations.C: Baffle function is internal and invisible; their purpose is hydraulic control and solids retention, not appearance.
explanations.D: Specific baffle positioning is required for proper tank function; improper positioning allows solids to enter and clog absorption fields.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, tests and services sewage treatment systems
questions.subtask: C-9.02 Installs components for sewage treatment systems
questions.question: What prevents a septic tank from floating when the water table is high?

options.A: Weight from contents or anchoring systems

explanations.A: Empty tanks can float in high groundwater; ballast, filling with water, or anchoring prevents flotation damage.
explanations.B: Empty tanks are buoyant and can float in saturated soil, potentially breaking connections and damaging the system.
explanations.C: Paint does not affect buoyancy; physical weight or anchoring is necessary to prevent flotation.
explanations.D: Flotation prevention requires engineering solutions including ballast or anchors; hope is not an effective strategy.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, tests and services sewage treatment systems
questions.subtask: C-9.02 Installs components for sewage treatment systems
questions.question: Why should vehicular traffic be kept off absorption fields?

options.A: Traffic is beneficial for absorption fields
options.B: Compaction destroys soil pore space needed for treatment and infiltration
options.D: Only to prevent visible tire marks

explanations.A: Traffic compaction is extremely damaging to absorption fields and must be prevented to maintain system function.
explanations.B: Compaction eliminates soil porosity essential for infiltration and treatment, causing absorption field failure.
explanations.C: Vehicle loads compact soil and crush piping, destroying absorption field function; traffic must be excluded.
explanations.D: While aesthetics are affected, the critical issue is soil compaction that destroys infiltration capacity and system function.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, tests and services sewage treatment systems
questions.subtask: C-9.03 Tests sewage treatment systems
questions.question: How is a septic tank typically tested for leaks after installation?

options.A: No testing is performed
options.B: Filled with water and monitored for level changes indicating leaks

explanations.A: Testing is essential to verify tank integrity before burial; leaking tanks contaminate groundwater and fail prematurely.
explanations.B: Water fill testing before backfilling reveals leaks through water level drops, allowing repairs before burial.
explanations.C: Testing provides objective verification of tank integrity; assumptions are inadequate for confirming watertight construction.
explanations.D: Visual inspection cannot detect all leak points; water testing provides definitive verification of tank integrity.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, tests and services sewage treatment systems
questions.subtask: C-9.03 Tests sewage treatment systems
questions.question: What must be verified in the distribution box during system testing?

options.A: That effluent distributes equally to all absorption lines

explanations.A: Equal distribution prevents overloading some lines while underusing others, maximizing absorption field efficiency and life.
explanations.B: Color is irrelevant; equal flow distribution to all lines is the critical functional requirement.
explanations.C: Equal distribution is essential for proper absorption field function; uneven flow causes premature localized failure.
explanations.D: Distribution testing ensures all absorption lines receive proper flow; uneven distribution causes system failure.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, tests and services sewage treatment systems
questions.subtask: C-9.03 Tests sewage treatment systems
questions.question: Why should absorption fields not be tested with water before use?

options.A: Water testing damages the biomat before establishment
options.B: Water testing is required before use

explanations.A: Water testing without the biological component can disturb soil and may affect biomat formation needed for proper function.
explanations.B: Unlike pressure systems, absorption fields typically are not water tested; they are verified through proper installation inspection.
explanations.C: The goal is maintaining soil structure and infiltrative capacity until the biomat properly forms during actual use.
explanations.D: Premature water loading can consolidate soil or disturb conditions; verification occurs through installation inspection, not water testing.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, tests and services sewage treatment systems
questions.subtask: C-9.03 Tests sewage treatment systems
questions.question: What inspections are required before a sewage treatment system is approved for use?

options.A: No inspections needed
options.B: Health department inspection of tank installation, absorption field construction, and system components
options.C: Only need to look at it briefly

explanations.A: Comprehensive inspections are mandatory to verify code compliance before burial and system startup.
explanations.B: Health authorities inspect all components before burial to verify proper installation and code compliance.
explanations.C: Thorough technical inspection verifying specifications is required; casual observation is insufficient for approval.
explanations.D: Inspections and approval are mandatory before systems can be covered and placed in service.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, tests and services sewage treatment systems
questions.subtask: C-9.03 Tests sewage treatment systems
questions.question: What documentation should be provided to the property owner after installation?

options.A: No documentation needed
options.B: As-built drawings, maintenance requirements, pumping schedule, and warranty information

explanations.A: Comprehensive documentation is essential for proper operation, maintenance, and future service of the system.
explanations.B: Complete documentation enables proper maintenance and provides reference information for future service and repairs.
explanations.C: Contact information alone is insufficient; technical documentation and maintenance requirements are essential.
explanations.D: Documentation is mandatory for owner education and ensuring proper system maintenance throughout its life.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, tests and services sewage treatment systems
questions.subtask: C-9.04 Services sewage treatment systems
questions.question: How frequently should septic tanks typically be pumped?

options.A: Never, they are maintenance-free
options.B: Every 2-5 years depending on tank size and usage

explanations.A: Septic tanks accumulate sludge and scum requiring periodic removal to prevent solids from entering absorption fields.
explanations.B: Regular pumping (typically 2-5 years) removes accumulated solids, maintaining capacity and protecting the absorption field.
explanations.C: Daily pumping is unnecessary and impractical; tanks are designed to accumulate solids between periodic pumping events.
explanations.D: 50-year intervals allow excessive buildup that damages absorption fields; much more frequent pumping is required.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, tests and services sewage treatment systems
questions.subtask: C-9.04 Services sewage treatment systems
questions.question: What indicates a septic system absorption field is failing?

options.A: Surfacing sewage, odors, wet areas, or backup into the building

explanations.A: Failure signs include surfacing effluent, odors, saturated soil, slow drains, or sewage backing up into the building.
explanations.B: These symptoms indicate problems requiring immediate attention; they do not represent proper operation.
explanations.C: Absorption fields can fail from age, solids loading, compaction, or hydraulic overload; failure is possible and requires intervention.
explanations.D: System failure decreases property value and creates health hazards; it does not improve property valuation.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, tests and services sewage treatment systems
questions.subtask: C-9.04 Services sewage treatment systems
questions.question: What can cause premature absorption field failure?

options.A: Excessive water use, lack of tank pumping, or soil compaction

explanations.A: Hydraulic overload, solids carryover from unpumped tanks, and soil compaction are common causes of premature failure.
explanations.B: Proper maintenance extends system life; neglect and abuse cause premature failures.
explanations.C: Following instructions promotes long system life; failures result from neglect, abuse, or adverse conditions.
explanations.D: Regular inspections help detect problems early; failures result from overload, neglect, or physical damage.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, tests and services sewage treatment systems
questions.subtask: C-9.04 Services sewage treatment systems
questions.question: Why should harsh chemicals not be used in septic systems?

options.A: Chemicals are beneficial for septic systems
options.B: They kill beneficial bacteria needed for waste decomposition

explanations.A: Harsh chemicals damage biological treatment processes essential for septic system function.
explanations.B: Chemicals kill beneficial bacteria performing decomposition in the tank, reducing treatment effectiveness and causing solids accumulation.
explanations.C: Chemicals disrupt biological processes; proper maintenance and bacterial activity improve performance, not chemicals.
explanations.D: Chemicals significantly impact system operation by killing essential bacteria; their use should be minimized.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, tests and services sewage treatment systems
questions.subtask: C-9.04 Services sewage treatment systems
questions.question: What maintenance is required for aerobic treatment units (ATUs)?

options.A: No maintenance needed
options.B: Regular inspections, air pump maintenance, and more frequent servicing than conventional septic systems

explanations.A: ATUs are mechanical systems requiring regular maintenance to ensure proper aeration and treatment.
explanations.B: ATUs need more frequent servicing including pump inspection, air filter cleaning, and treatment monitoring to maintain function.
explanations.C: ATUs require more maintenance than passive septic tanks due to mechanical components needing regular service.
explanations.D: Regular maintenance is essential for ATUs; neglect causes system failure and violates discharge permits.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, tests and services sewage treatment systems
questions.subtask: C-9.04 Services sewage treatment systems
questions.question: How can homeowners help maintain their septic system?

options.A: Conserve water, avoid flushing inappropriate items, schedule regular pumping, and avoid chemical overuse

explanations.A: Water conservation, proper waste disposal, regular pumping, and chemical avoidance extend system life and ensure proper function.
explanations.B: Grease clogs absorption fields and should never be disposed through septic systems; proper disposal is essential.
explanations.C: Non-biodegradable items clog systems; only toilet paper and human waste should be flushed.
explanations.D: Regular pumping is essential to remove accumulated solids and prevent absorption field damage from solids carryover.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, tests and services sewage treatment systems
questions.subtask: C-9.04 Services sewage treatment systems
questions.question: What should be done if a septic system shows signs of failure?

options.A: Ignore it and hope it improves
options.B: Contact a qualified professional for assessment and repair
options.C: Add more water to dilute the problem

explanations.A: Ignoring failures allows contamination to spread and problems to worsen; prompt professional intervention is necessary.
explanations.B: Professional assessment determines failure cause and appropriate repairs, preventing health hazards and further damage.
explanations.C: Adding water to failing systems worsens the overload; reducing water use and professional repair are necessary.
explanations.D: Covering symptoms does not address underlying causes; professional diagnosis and repair are required.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, tests and services interior drainage, waste and vent (DWV) systems
questions.subtask: C-10.01 Plans layout and sizes piping for DWV systems
questions.question: What does DWV stand for in plumbing terminology?

options.A: Drainage, Waste, and Vent

explanations.A: DWV stands for Drainage, Waste, and Vent systems that remove wastewater and provide venting for proper operation.
explanations.B: This is not the meaning of DWV; the acronym specifically refers to drainage and venting systems.
explanations.C: While drainage is part of DWV, this is not the correct interpretation of the acronym.
explanations.D: DWV is a plumbing system designation, not a vessel reference; it relates to drainage and venting.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, tests and services interior drainage, waste and vent (DWV) systems
questions.subtask: C-10.01 Plans layout and sizes piping for DWV systems
questions.question: What is the minimum slope required for a 75 mm (3-inch) horizontal drainage pipe?

options.A: 1/8 inch per foot (1%)

explanations.A: 1/8 inch per foot is insufficient for drainage pipes and will result in solids deposition and blockages.
explanations.B: Most codes require 1/4 inch per foot minimum slope for 75 mm (3-inch) drainage piping to maintain adequate flow velocity.
explanations.C: 1/2 inch per foot exceeds minimum requirements and would be acceptable but uses more vertical space unnecessarily.
explanations.D: Level pipes allow solids to settle and create blockages; minimum slope is essential for proper drainage.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, tests and services interior drainage, waste and vent (DWV) systems
questions.subtask: C-10.01 Plans layout and sizes piping for DWV systems
questions.question: What is a fixture unit and how is it used in DWV sizing?

options.A: A measure of measurement used to size drainage piping based on cumulative fixture loads
options.D: Fixture units are not used in plumbing

explanations.A: Fixture units are standardized load values assigned to fixtures, used to calculate and size drainage and vent piping.
explanations.B: Fixture units measure discharge load, not physical weight; they represent flow demand for sizing purposes.
explanations.C: Fixture units are technical sizing parameters, not financial values; they relate to flow capacity requirements.
explanations.D: Fixture units are fundamental to plumbing design, providing standardized method for sizing drainage systems.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, tests and services interior drainage, waste and vent (DWV) systems
questions.subtask: C-10.01 Plans layout and sizes piping for DWV systems
questions.question: Why must drainage pipes increase in size as they progress downstream?

options.A: To accommodate cumulative flow from additional fixtures connecting along the run
options.C: Pipes never increase in size downstream

explanations.A: As more fixtures connect, cumulative flow increases requiring larger pipe sizes to maintain adequate capacity and velocity.
explanations.B: While velocity is a consideration, the primary reason for upsizing is accommodating increased flow from additional fixtures.
explanations.C: Drainage pipes must increase in size as additional fixtures add to the cumulative load downstream.
explanations.D: Pipe sizing is based on hydraulic requirements, not aesthetics; proper sizing ensures adequate capacity.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, tests and services interior drainage, waste and vent (DWV) systems
questions.subtask: C-10.01 Plans layout and sizes piping for DWV systems
questions.question: What is the purpose of a vent system in DWV installations?

options.A: To heat the drainage system
options.B: To maintain atmospheric pressure in drainage pipes, enabling proper flow and preventing trap siphonage
options.C: To add water to the system

explanations.A: Vents do not heat systems; they provide air circulation to maintain proper pressure for drainage and trap seal protection.
explanations.B: Vents allow air entry to prevent vacuum formation, enable proper drainage flow, and protect trap seals from siphonage.
explanations.C: Vents provide air, not water; they balance pressure to enable proper drainage system function.
explanations.D: Vents are essential for proper drainage system operation; they prevent trap seal loss and enable adequate flow.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, tests and services interior drainage, waste and vent (DWV) systems
questions.subtask: C-10.01 Plans layout and sizes piping for DWV systems
questions.question: What is the minimum size for a water closet drain?

options.A: 38 mm (1.5 inches)

explanations.A: 38 mm is far too small for toilet drainage and would cause immediate blockages.
explanations.B: 50 mm is insufficient for toilet waste; larger diameter is required for solids passage.
explanations.C: Water closets require minimum 75 mm (3-inch) drains to accommodate solid waste passage, though 100 mm is more common.
explanations.D: While 100 mm is commonly used for toilets, the code minimum is typically 75 mm for individual toilet drains.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, tests and services interior drainage, waste and vent (DWV) systems
questions.subtask: C-10.01 Plans layout and sizes piping for DWV systems
questions.question: What is a trap seal and why is it important?

options.A: Water remaining in trap to block sewer gases from entering the building

explanations.A: The trap seal is the water barrier in fixture traps that prevents sewer gases and odors from entering occupied spaces.
explanations.B: Trap seals are water barriers, not mechanical devices; they rely on gravity and water column to block gases.
explanations.C: While traps are fittings, the trap seal specifically refers to the water barrier preventing gas entry.
explanations.D: Trap seals are critical for health and safety, preventing toxic and odorous sewer gases from entering buildings.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, tests and services interior drainage, waste and vent (DWV) systems
questions.subtask: C-10.01 Plans layout and sizes piping for DWV systems
questions.question: Where should cleanouts be located in DWV systems?

options.A: Randomly throughout the system
options.B: At base of stacks, direction changes, and maximum spacing intervals for maintenance access

explanations.A: Cleanout locations follow code requirements for strategic access points, not random placement.
explanations.B: Cleanouts at stacks, direction changes, and regular intervals ensure access for clearing blockages throughout the system.
explanations.C: Cleanouts are required by code at specific locations to enable system maintenance and blockage clearing.
explanations.D: While exterior cleanouts are valuable, interior locations at stacks and direction changes are also required.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, tests and services interior drainage, waste and vent (DWV) systems
questions.subtask: C-10.02 Installs underground piping for DWV systems
questions.question: What bedding material should be used under underground drainage piping?

options.A: Rocky native soil
options.B: Graded sand or crushed stone providing uniform support

explanations.A: Rocky soil creates point loads damaging pipe; proper granular bedding distributes loads uniformly.
explanations.B: Graded granular bedding provides uniform support, prevents point loads, and facilitates drainage around underground piping.
explanations.C: Clay retains water and provides inconsistent support; free-draining granular material is specified for pipe bedding.
explanations.D: Proper bedding is essential for supporting underground pipe and preventing damage from uneven loads.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, tests and services interior drainage, waste and vent (DWV) systems
questions.subtask: C-10.02 Installs underground piping for DWV systems
questions.question: Why must underground drainage piping maintain proper grade?

options.A: Grade is not important for drains
options.B: To ensure gravity flow with adequate velocity to transport solids without deposition

explanations.A: Grade is critical for gravity drainage systems; improper slope causes flow problems and blockages.
explanations.B: Proper slope ensures adequate flow velocity to transport solids while preventing excessive velocity that could cause problems.
explanations.C: Grade is functional requirement for proper flow; underground piping appearance is not visible or relevant.
explanations.D: The goal is maintaining proper velocity, not slowing flow; adequate velocity prevents solids deposition.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, tests and services interior drainage, waste and vent (DWV) systems
questions.subtask: C-10.02 Installs underground piping for DWV systems
questions.question: What must be done where underground drains pass through foundation walls?

options.A: Cut tight hole with no clearance
options.B: Install sleeves allowing pipe movement and seal penetration
options.C: Break the pipe at the wall

explanations.A: Tight penetrations restrict movement and can stress pipes or crack foundations; sleeves are required.
explanations.B: Sleeves protect pipe, allow for movement, and enable waterproof sealing of the penetration through the foundation.
explanations.C: Continuous piping through walls is required; breaking pipes creates leak points and violates codes.
explanations.D: Foundation penetrations require sleeves and sealing to maintain structural integrity and prevent water infiltration.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, tests and services interior drainage, waste and vent (DWV) systems
questions.subtask: C-10.02 Installs underground piping for DWV systems
questions.question: Why should underground drainage pipes be protected from tree roots?

options.A: Trees benefit sewer systems
options.B: Roots seek moisture, can penetrate joints causing blockages and damage

explanations.A: Tree roots cause significant drainage problems; they are a primary cause of sewer line damage and blockages.
explanations.B: Roots grow toward water sources, penetrating joints and causing blockages requiring expensive clearing and repairs.
explanations.C: Root protection through joint sealing, barriers, or distance is important for preventing costly future problems.
explanations.D: Roots are highly effective at finding and penetrating drainage lines, causing blockages and structural damage.
