questions.taskTitle: Installs, tests and services interior drainage, waste and vent (DWV) systems
questions.subtask: C-10.02 Installs underground piping for DWV systems
questions.question: What is the purpose of a building trap in underground drainage systems?

options.A: To provide a water seal preventing sewer gases from entering building drainage

explanations.A: Building traps create a water barrier preventing sewer gases from traveling back into the building drainage system.
explanations.B: Traps are flow-through water seals, not storage devices; they block gases while allowing waste to flow through.
explanations.C: Traps are passive water seals and do not heat drainage; they block gases through water barrier.
explanations.D: While not universally required, building traps are used in some jurisdictions to isolate building drainage from sewer gases.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, tests and services interior drainage, waste and vent (DWV) systems
questions.subtask: C-10.02 Installs underground piping for DWV systems
questions.question: Why must underground drainage piping be tested before burial?

options.A: Testing is optional
options.B: To verify system is watertight and properly graded before covering, when repairs are easier

explanations.A: Testing before burial is mandatory to detect defects when correction is practical; buried defects are costly to repair.
explanations.B: Pre-burial testing verifies leak-tight installation and proper grade while system is accessible for efficient correction.
explanations.C: Testing serves critical functional purposes verifying system integrity; appearance is not relevant for buried piping.
explanations.D: Testing prevents costly future failures and ensures code compliance; it is essential quality assurance, not waste.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, tests and services interior drainage, waste and vent (DWV) systems
questions.subtask: C-10.02 Installs underground piping for DWV systems
questions.question: What backfill material should be used around underground drainage pipes?

options.A: Large rocks and construction debris
options.B: Granular material free of rocks, compacted in layers

explanations.A: Rocks and debris create point loads and voids that can damage pipe; proper backfill provides uniform support.
explanations.B: Rock-free granular material compacted in layers provides uniform support and protection without damaging pipe.
explanations.C: Clay soil is difficult to compact properly and retains water; free-draining granular material is preferred.
explanations.D: Backfill quality is critical for pipe protection; proper material selection and placement prevent damage and settlement.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, tests and services interior drainage, waste and vent (DWV) systems
questions.subtask: C-10.02 Installs underground piping for DWV systems
questions.question: How should the connection between underground drainage and the building sewer be made?

options.A: With proper fittings maintaining required slope and alignment
options.D: Use rope to tie pipes together

explanations.A: Proper fittings ensure smooth flow transition, maintain grade, and create leak-free connections between building drain and sewer.
explanations.B: Random angles create turbulence and solids accumulation; proper fitting angles ensure smooth flow.
explanations.C: Proper connection between building drainage and sewer is essential for system function and code compliance.
explanations.D: Permanent, sealed pipe connections using proper fittings are required; rope cannot create sanitary connections.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, tests and services interior drainage, waste and vent (DWV) systems
questions.subtask: C-10.03 Installs above-ground piping for DWV systems
questions.question: What support spacing is required for vertical drainage stacks?

options.A: No support needed
options.B: At each floor level or at maximum code-specified intervals

explanations.A: Vertical stacks require support to carry pipe weight and prevent joint stress from cumulative loading.
explanations.B: Stacks must be supported at each floor level and at maximum intervals specified by code for the pipe material.
explanations.C: Top-only support allows excessive stress on lower joints; multi-level support is required for tall stacks.
explanations.D: 100-foot spacing far exceeds safe support intervals; much closer spacing is required for vertical stacks.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, tests and services interior drainage, waste and vent (DWV) systems
questions.subtask: C-10.03 Installs above-ground piping for DWV systems
questions.question: Why must drainage fittings have smooth interior flow paths?

options.A: Only for appearance
options.B: To prevent solids accumulation and blockages by maintaining flow velocity

explanations.A: Interior smoothness affects flow performance; drainage system interiors are not visible for aesthetic purposes.
explanations.B: Smooth flow paths maintain velocity, prevent turbulence that deposits solids, and minimize blockage risk.
explanations.C: Flow path geometry is critical in drainage; sharp corners and rough surfaces cause solids accumulation and blockages.
explanations.D: Smooth fittings are specified for functional drainage performance, though they may cost more than unsuitable alternatives.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, tests and services interior drainage, waste and vent (DWV) systems
questions.subtask: C-10.03 Installs above-ground piping for DWV systems
questions.question: What is the purpose of a vent stack in a multi-story building?

options.A: To vent atmospheric pressure throughout the drainage system protecting trap seals
options.B: To supply water to upper floors

explanations.A: Vent stacks provide air circulation to maintain atmospheric pressure, enabling proper drainage and protecting all trap seals.
explanations.B: Vent stacks carry air, not water; water supply uses separate pressurized piping systems.
explanations.C: Vents provide air circulation for drainage function; they do not heat buildings or drainage systems.
explanations.D: Vent stacks are essential for proper drainage system operation in multi-story buildings; they prevent trap seal loss.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, tests and services interior drainage, waste and vent (DWV) systems
questions.subtask: C-10.03 Installs above-ground piping for DWV systems
questions.question: Why must horizontal drainage pipes have proper support spacing?

options.A: To prevent sagging that would create low spots where solids accumulate
options.B: Support is not needed for horizontal pipes

explanations.A: Proper support prevents sagging that creates bellies where solids and liquids accumulate, causing blockages.
explanations.B: Horizontal pipes require support to prevent sagging from their weight and the weight of contents.
explanations.C: Proper support maintains designed grade for function; sagging affects drainage performance regardless of visibility.
explanations.D: Support requirements ensure proper function; they are engineering necessities, not arbitrary complications.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, tests and services interior drainage, waste and vent (DWV) systems
questions.subtask: C-10.04 Tests DWV systems
questions.question: How is a water test performed on a DWV system?

options.A: Visual inspection only
options.B: Fill system with water to specified height and monitor for leaks

explanations.A: Visual inspection cannot detect all leaks; pressure testing with water provides definitive verification.
explanations.B: Water testing fills the system to specified head and monitors for level drops or visible leaks before enclosure.
explanations.C: While leaks may produce sounds, visual monitoring of water level and leak points is the reliable test method.
explanations.D: Water testing is a standard method for verifying DWV system integrity before closing in walls and ceilings.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, tests and services interior drainage, waste and vent (DWV) systems
questions.subtask: C-10.04 Tests DWV systems
questions.question: What is an air test for DWV systems?

options.A: Pressurize system with low-pressure air and monitor for pressure loss indicating leaks

explanations.A: Air testing pressurizes the system with low-pressure air (typically 5 psi) and monitors for pressure decay indicating leaks.
explanations.B: Proper air testing uses gauges and controlled pressure; casual blowing cannot detect leaks or verify integrity.
explanations.C: Air testing is a common alternative to water testing for verifying DWV system leak-tightness.
explanations.D: Air testing verifies system integrity through pressure monitoring, not air quality analysis.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, tests and services interior drainage, waste and vent (DWV) systems
questions.subtask: C-10.04 Tests DWV systems
questions.question: What pressure is typically used for air testing drainage systems?

options.A: 100 psi

explanations.A: 100 psi is far too high for drainage system testing and could damage pipe and joints.
explanations.B: Drainage systems are typically air tested at 34 kPa (5 psi), sufficient to detect leaks without risking damage.
explanations.C: 500 psi would be extremely dangerous and damage drainage systems; much lower pressure is used.
explanations.D: 1000 psi is absurdly high for gravity drainage systems; testing uses very low pressures in the 5 psi range.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, tests and services interior drainage, waste and vent (DWV) systems
questions.subtask: C-10.04 Tests DWV systems
questions.question: Why are DWV systems tested before walls and ceilings are closed?

options.A: To detect and repair leaks while system is accessible

explanations.A: Testing before enclosure allows efficient leak detection and repair; fixing buried defects is extremely costly.
explanations.B: Testing after enclosure is impractical as defects cannot be easily accessed for repair without destructive investigation.
explanations.C: Testing is mandatory before enclosure to verify code compliance and prevent costly future repairs.
explanations.D: Testing serves critical quality assurance functions; DWV systems are hidden, making appearance irrelevant.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, tests and services interior drainage, waste and vent (DWV) systems
questions.subtask: C-10.05 Services DWV systems
questions.question: What is the most common cause of drain blockages in residential systems?

options.A: Proper use of fixtures
options.B: Hair, grease, soap scum, and inappropriate items flushed or drained

explanations.A: Proper use prevents blockages; improper disposal of materials causes most drain obstructions.
explanations.B: Hair, grease, soap residue, and inappropriate items like wipes cause most residential drain blockages.
explanations.C: Adequate water actually helps flush drains; insufficient water use contributes more to blockages.
explanations.D: Blockages are common maintenance issues in drainage systems requiring periodic cleaning and proper use.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, tests and services interior drainage, waste and vent (DWV) systems
questions.subtask: C-10.05 Services DWV systems
questions.question: How should a drain snake (auger) be used to clear blockages?

options.A: Force it violently through pipes
options.B: Feed cable slowly while rotating to engage and break up obstruction

explanations.A: Violent forcing can damage pipes and fittings; controlled advancement with rotation is proper technique.
explanations.B: Gradual advancement with rotation allows the auger head to engage blockages and break them up without pipe damage.
explanations.C: Premature pulling withdraws the snake before engaging the blockage; proper technique requires advancing to obstruction first.
explanations.D: Drain snakes are standard tools for mechanical blockage removal in drainage systems.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, tests and services interior drainage, waste and vent (DWV) systems
questions.subtask: C-10.05 Services DWV systems
questions.question: Why should chemical drain cleaners be used with caution?

options.A: Chemicals are completely safe for all applications
options.B: They can damage pipes, are hazardous to handle, and may not resolve blockages

explanations.A: Chemical cleaners can damage certain pipe materials and create hazardous conditions; caution is required.
explanations.B: Chemical cleaners can corrode pipes, create hazardous fumes, cause burns, and may fail to clear complete blockages.
explanations.C: Chemicals often fail to resolve blockages completely and may worsen some situations; mechanical clearing is more reliable.
explanations.D: Excessive chemicals increase damage risk and hazards without improving effectiveness; more is not better.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, tests and services interior drainage, waste and vent (DWV) systems
questions.subtask: C-10.05 Services DWV systems
questions.question: What maintenance should be performed on floor drains?

options.A: No maintenance needed
options.B: Periodic flushing to maintain trap seal and cleaning to remove debris

explanations.A: Floor drains require maintenance to keep trap seals filled and remove accumulated debris preventing blockages.
explanations.B: Regular water addition maintains trap seals, while cleaning removes debris that could cause blockages or odors.
explanations.C: Sealing floor drains eliminates their drainage function; they must remain operational for floor drainage.
explanations.D: Regular chemical use is unnecessary and potentially harmful; water flushing and mechanical cleaning are appropriate maintenance.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, tests and services interior drainage, waste and vent (DWV) systems
questions.subtask: C-10.05 Services DWV systems
questions.question: What causes a trap seal to be lost, allowing sewer gases into the building?

options.A: Proper venting
options.B: Siphonage from inadequate venting, evaporation, or capillary action

explanations.A: Proper venting prevents trap seal loss; inadequate venting is a primary cause of seal failure.
explanations.B: Siphonage from poor venting, evaporation in unused fixtures, and wicking by debris can deplete trap seals.
explanations.C: Trap seals can fail through multiple mechanisms requiring attention to venting and periodic use.
explanations.D: Adequate water maintains seals; insufficient use allowing evaporation causes seal loss.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, tests and services interior drainage, waste and vent (DWV) systems
questions.subtask: C-10.05 Services DWV systems
questions.question: How can fixture traps be maintained to prevent odor problems?

options.A: Seal all vents
options.B: Regular use maintaining trap seals, proper venting, and periodic cleaning

explanations.A: Sealing vents causes trap siphonage and drainage problems; proper venting maintains trap seals.
explanations.B: Regular fixture use maintains water seals, proper venting prevents siphonage, and cleaning removes odor-causing buildup.
explanations.C: Grease causes blockages and odors; it should never be poured down drains but disposed of properly.
explanations.D: Disconnecting traps eliminates their essential function of blocking sewer gases; traps must remain functional.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, tests and services interior drainage, waste and vent (DWV) systems
questions.subtask: C-10.05 Services DWV systems
questions.question: What should be done if multiple fixtures are draining slowly?

options.A: Indicates a blockage in the common drain requiring professional clearing

explanations.A: Multiple slow drains indicate blockage in the shared drain line requiring clearing of the common section.
explanations.B: Ignoring the problem allows blockages to worsen, potentially causing complete stoppage and backups.
explanations.C: Adding water to partially blocked drains risks overflow; clearing the obstruction is necessary.
explanations.D: While individual traps might be checked, multiple fixture problems indicate common line blockage downstream.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, tests and services interior drainage, waste and vent (DWV) systems
questions.subtask: C-10.05 Services DWV systems
questions.question: Why should vent terminals be checked and cleared?

options.A: Vent blockage prevents proper system venting causing drainage problems and trap seal loss

explanations.A: Blocked vents prevent air circulation, causing slow drainage, gurgling, and trap seal siphonage throughout the system.
explanations.B: Vent terminals can become blocked by debris, nests, or ice requiring periodic inspection and clearing.
explanations.C: Vent blockages cause system malfunction including slow drainage and sewer gas entry; they severely degrade performance.
explanations.D: Vent function is critical for drainage system operation; their role is functional, not aesthetic.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, tests and services interior drainage, waste and vent (DWV) systems
questions.subtask: C-10.05 Services DWV systems
questions.question: What is the purpose of using a plunger on a clogged drain?

options.A: To create pressure waves to dislodge blockages
options.B: To add water to the drain

explanations.A: Plunging creates alternating pressure and suction to dislodge soft blockages without chemicals or tools.
explanations.B: While water presence helps plunger effectiveness, the primary function is creating pressure waves to clear blockages.
explanations.C: Plungers are effective first-response tools for many soft blockages before resorting to chemicals or mechanical snakes.
explanations.D: Plungers are functional tools for clearing blockages; they serve practical maintenance purposes.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, tests and services interior drainage, waste and vent (DWV) systems
questions.subtask: C-10.05 Services DWV systems
questions.question: How can root intrusion into drainage lines be prevented?

options.A: Root intrusion cannot be prevented
options.B: Through proper joint sealing, chemical root treatments, or physical barriers

explanations.A: Root intrusion can be prevented or minimized through proper installation and preventive treatments.
explanations.B: Tight joints, root-inhibiting chemicals, and physical barriers help prevent root penetration into drainage lines.
explanations.C: Trees near drainage lines increase root intrusion risk; separation or barriers are needed for protection.
explanations.D: Roots cause blockages and pipe damage; they are a major maintenance problem, not beneficial.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, tests and services interior drainage, waste and vent (DWV) systems
questions.subtask: C-10.05 Services DWV systems
questions.question: Why should grease not be poured down drains?

options.A: Grease helps clean pipes
options.B: Grease solidifies in pipes causing stubborn blockages
options.D: Grease disposal down drains is recommended

explanations.A: Grease accumulates in pipes rather than cleaning them; it is a primary cause of drainage blockages.
explanations.B: Grease solidifies as it cools, coating pipe interiors and trapping debris, creating blockages requiring professional removal.
explanations.C: Grease impairs drainage by coating pipes and accumulating debris; it significantly degrades system performance.
explanations.D: Grease should never go down drains; proper disposal in trash containers prevents plumbing problems.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, tests and services interior drainage, waste and vent (DWV) systems
questions.subtask: C-10.05 Services DWV systems
questions.question: What indicates a drainage system needs professional video inspection?

options.A: Recurring blockages, slow drainage throughout system, or suspected structural problems

explanations.A: Persistent problems suggest underlying issues like root intrusion, pipe collapse, or improper installation requiring inspection.
explanations.B: Perfect performance indicates no inspection need; video inspection diagnoses persistent problems.
explanations.C: Video inspection is valuable for diagnosing persistent drainage problems and planning repairs.
explanations.D: Video inspection is a professional diagnostic tool for assessing system condition and identifying specific problems.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, tests and services interior drainage, waste and vent (DWV) systems
questions.subtask: C-10.01 Plans layout and sizes piping for DWV systems
questions.question: What is wet venting in DWV systems?

options.A: Using water to clean vents
options.B: A drainage pipe serving as both drain and vent for fixtures upstream

explanations.A: Wet venting is a piping configuration, not a cleaning method; it serves dual drainage and venting functions.
explanations.B: Wet venting allows a drain pipe to also provide venting for fixtures discharging upstream, with specific code requirements.
explanations.C: Wet venting is an effective code-approved method when properly designed and installed per specifications.
explanations.D: Wet venting is a drainage system configuration combining drain and vent functions, not heating equipment.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, tests and services interior drainage, waste and vent (DWV) systems
questions.subtask: C-10.01 Plans layout and sizes piping for DWV systems
questions.question: What is the maximum distance from a trap to its vent for a 50 mm (2-inch) drain?

options.A: Unlimited distance
options.B: Typically 1.5 to 2 meters (5 to 6.5 feet) depending on local codes

explanations.A: Maximum trap arm lengths are specified to prevent trap seal loss through self-siphonage.
explanations.B: Codes limit trap arm length based on pipe size to prevent siphonage; 50 mm typically allows 1.5-2 meters.
explanations.C: Excessive trap arm length would cause trap seal siphonage; codes specify much shorter maximum distances.
explanations.D: Distance is critical; excessive trap arm length allows siphonage depleting trap seals and allowing gas entry.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, tests and services interior drainage, waste and vent (DWV) systems
questions.subtask: C-10.01 Plans layout and sizes piping for DWV systems
questions.question: Why must drainage systems have adequate capacity for future expansion?

options.A: Future expansion is never considered
options.B: To accommodate additional fixtures without requiring complete system replacement

explanations.A: Prudent design considers reasonable future needs to avoid costly complete replacement for modest additions.
explanations.B: Oversizing for anticipated growth allows fixture additions without replacing major drain and vent runs.
explanations.C: Reasonable capacity allowance is cost-effective long-term planning preventing expensive future replacements.
explanations.D: Proper sizing for future loads does not reduce life; inadequate capacity for growth requires costly premature replacement.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, tests and services interior drainage, waste and vent (DWV) systems
questions.subtask: C-10.01 Plans layout and sizes piping for DWV systems
questions.question: What is a stack vent?

options.A: The extension of a soil or waste stack above the highest fixture connection

explanations.A: The stack vent is the upper portion of the drainage stack extending above fixtures to atmosphere, providing system venting.
explanations.B: Stack vents are passive air pipes, not mechanical exhaust equipment; they provide natural drainage system venting.
explanations.C: Stack vents are air pipes, not water storage; they ventilate drainage systems to atmosphere.
explanations.D: Stack vents are essential components extending drainage stacks to roof level for atmospheric venting.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, tests and services interior drainage, waste and vent (DWV) systems
questions.subtask: C-10.02 Installs underground piping for DWV systems
questions.question: Why should changes of direction in underground drains use long-sweep fittings?

options.A: To maintain flow velocity and prevent solids deposition at bends

explanations.A: Long-sweep fittings maintain flow momentum and reduce turbulence, preventing solids from settling at direction changes.
explanations.B: Short-radius fittings create turbulence and solids deposition; long-sweep fittings are required for drainage.
explanations.C: Fitting geometry significantly affects flow; proper long-sweep fittings prevent blockages at direction changes.
explanations.D: Long-sweep fittings prevent blockages through improved flow characteristics; they are specified to reduce problems.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, tests and services interior drainage, waste and vent (DWV) systems
questions.subtask: C-10.03 Installs above-ground piping for DWV systems
questions.question: What is an air admittance valve (AAV)?

options.A: One-way valve allowing air into drainage system while preventing gas escape
options.D: AAVs are not used in plumbing

explanations.A: AAVs allow air entry to prevent vacuum while sealing against sewer gas escape, serving as localized venting.
explanations.B: AAVs are drainage system air valves, not water control devices; they provide venting without roof penetrations.
explanations.C: AAVs are mechanical venting devices for drainage systems, not heating equipment.
explanations.D: AAVs are code-approved venting solutions in many jurisdictions for specific applications where conventional venting is impractical.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, tests and services interior drainage, waste and vent (DWV) systems
questions.subtask: C-10.04 Tests DWV systems
questions.question: What is smoke testing used for in DWV systems?

options.A: To identify leaks and improper connections by observing smoke escape points

explanations.A: Non-toxic smoke introduced under pressure reveals leaks and cross-connections where smoke escapes from the system.
explanations.B: Smoke testing is a diagnostic technique using visible smoke to locate defects, not a heating method.
explanations.C: Smoke testing serves functional diagnostic purposes identifying system defects, not aesthetic goals.
explanations.D: Smoke testing is a valuable diagnostic tool for locating leaks and improper connections in drainage systems.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, tests and services interior drainage, waste and vent (DWV) systems
questions.subtask: C-10.05 Services DWV systems
questions.question: What causes gurgling sounds in drains?

options.A: Perfect drainage function
options.B: Inadequate venting creating air movement through trap seals

explanations.A: Gurgling indicates problems with venting or partial blockages; it does not represent proper drainage operation.
explanations.B: Gurgling occurs when inadequate venting forces air through trap seals, indicating venting problems or partial blockages.
explanations.C: Insufficient venting causes gurgling; adequate venting prevents these sounds by providing proper air circulation.
explanations.D: Gurgling indicates drainage problems requiring attention; it signals venting inadequacy or partial obstructions.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, tests and services interior drainage, waste and vent (DWV) systems
questions.subtask: C-10.01 Plans layout and sizes piping for DWV systems
questions.question: What is a circuit vent?

options.A: A branch vent serving two or more traps connected to a horizontal drain

explanations.A: Circuit vents branch from horizontal drains serving multiple fixtures, providing venting where individual vents are impractical.
explanations.B: Circuit vents are plumbing drainage venting components, not electrical system elements.
explanations.C: Circuit vents are passive air pipes in drainage systems, not mechanical ventilation fans.
explanations.D: Circuit vents are code-recognized venting methods for specific multiple-fixture drainage configurations.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, tests and services interior drainage, waste and vent (DWV) systems
questions.subtask: C-10.02 Installs underground piping for DWV systems
questions.question: Why must underground drainage pipes be laid to line and grade?

options.A: For appearance only
options.B: To ensure consistent slope for proper gravity flow and prevent solids accumulation
options.C: Line and grade are not important

explanations.A: Underground drainage is not visible; proper line and grade ensure functional gravity drainage.
explanations.B: Precise line and grade maintain designed slope throughout, ensuring adequate flow velocity and preventing solids deposition.
explanations.C: Accurate line and grade are essential for gravity drainage function; deviations cause flow problems and blockages.
explanations.D: Random installation creates bellies and improper slopes causing blockages; precision is essential for proper function.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, tests and services interior drainage, waste and vent (DWV) systems
questions.subtask: C-10.03 Installs above-ground piping for DWV systems
questions.question: What special considerations apply when installing drainage piping in fire-rated assemblies?

options.A: No special considerations needed
options.B: Penetrations must be firestopped to maintain fire rating
options.D: Fire ratings don't apply to plumbing

explanations.A: Fire-rated penetrations require specific firestopping to restore fire resistance ratings compromised by piping.
explanations.B: Drainage pipe penetrations through fire-rated assemblies must be firestopped to maintain the fire resistance rating.
explanations.C: Wooden pipes are not used in modern plumbing; proper material and firestopping maintain fire ratings.
explanations.D: Plumbing penetrations can compromise fire ratings; proper firestopping is required for code compliance.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, tests and services interior drainage, waste and vent (DWV) systems
questions.subtask: C-10.05 Services DWV systems
questions.question: What preventive maintenance helps avoid drainage system problems?

options.A: Regular professional inspection, proper fixture use, avoiding inappropriate disposals, and periodic cleaning

explanations.A: Regular inspections, proper use, appropriate disposal practices, and periodic cleaning prevent most drainage problems.
explanations.B: Neglecting maintenance allows small problems to become major failures; regular attention prevents costly repairs.
explanations.C: Improper disposal is the primary cause of drain problems; proper waste handling prevents most blockages.
explanations.D: Addressing early warning signs prevents escalation to major problems; prompt attention is essential preventive maintenance.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, tests and services interior drainage, waste and vent (DWV) systems
questions.subtask: C-10.01 Plans layout and sizes piping for DWV systems
questions.question: What is a common vent in drainage systems?

options.A: A vent serving two fixture traps installed at the same level

explanations.A: A common vent serves two fixture traps located at the same level and connected at a common point on the drainage system.
explanations.B: Common vents are specific drainage system configurations, not building-wide mechanical ventilation systems.
explanations.C: Common vents are passive air pipes serving two fixtures, not powered mechanical ventilation equipment.
explanations.D: Common vents are code-approved configurations for specific two-fixture arrangements meeting spacing requirements.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, tests and services interior drainage, waste and vent (DWV) systems
questions.subtask: C-10.01 Plans layout and sizes piping for DWV systems
questions.question: Why must vertical drainage stacks be straight and plumb?

options.A: To maintain consistent flow velocity and prevent solids accumulation
options.C: Stacks don't need to be straight

explanations.A: Straight plumb stacks maintain proper flow characteristics, prevent clinging of solids, and facilitate cleaning.
explanations.B: While appearance may be affected in visible areas, the critical reasons are hydraulic performance and cleanability.
explanations.C: Offsets and deviations in stacks create turbulence and potential blockage points; straight vertical runs are required.
explanations.D: Straight installation ensures proper function; this is an engineering requirement, not arbitrary complication.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, tests and services interior drainage, waste and vent (DWV) systems
questions.subtask: C-10.01 Plans layout and sizes piping for DWV systems
questions.question: What is the purpose of a relief vent in tall drainage stacks?

options.A: To provide additional air circulation preventing pressure fluctuations in tall stacks
options.B: To add water to the system

explanations.A: Relief vents in tall buildings provide auxiliary venting to prevent pressure and vacuum conditions that could affect trap seals.
explanations.B: Relief vents are air pipes providing pressure equalization, not water supply components.
explanations.C: Relief vents are important in tall buildings where stack pressure variations could compromise trap seals.
explanations.D: Relief vents provide pressure equalization through air circulation, not heating functions.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, tests and services interior drainage, waste and vent (DWV) systems
questions.subtask: C-10.01 Plans layout and sizes piping for DWV systems
questions.question: What is the minimum trap seal depth required by most plumbing codes?

options.A: 25 mm (1 inch)

explanations.A: 25 mm is insufficient depth to reliably block gases and resist siphonage; greater depth is required.
explanations.B: Most codes require minimum 50 mm (2-inch) trap seal depth to effectively block gases while resisting siphonage.
explanations.C: 100 mm exceeds typical requirements and would create excessive flow resistance; standard is around 50 mm.
explanations.D: Minimum trap seal depth is specified to ensure adequate gas blockage; depth requirements prevent seal loss.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, tests and services interior drainage, waste and vent (DWV) systems
questions.subtask: C-10.01 Plans layout and sizes piping for DWV systems
questions.question: Why should fixture drains not be trapped twice?

options.A: Double trapping creates areas where solids accumulate and causes drainage problems
options.D: Double trapping is required by code

explanations.A: Double trapped fixtures create sections between traps where water and solids accumulate, causing blockages and slow drainage.
explanations.B: Additional traps impede drainage by creating siphon-prone sections and areas where material accumulates.
explanations.C: Single properly vented traps are effective; additional traps create problems rather than improving performance.
explanations.D: Codes prohibit double trapping except in specific approved applications; it generally causes drainage dysfunction.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, tests and services interior drainage, waste and vent (DWV) systems
questions.subtask: C-10.01 Plans layout and sizes piping for DWV systems
questions.question: What size pipe is typically used for a kitchen sink drain?

options.A: 32 mm (1.25 inches)

explanations.A: 32 mm is too small for kitchen sinks which discharge food particles; larger diameter prevents blockages.
explanations.B: Kitchen sinks typically use 38 mm (1.5-inch) or larger drains to handle discharge loads including food particles.
explanations.C: While 50 mm would work, it exceeds typical requirements; 38 mm is the standard minimum for kitchen sinks.
explanations.D: 100 mm is excessive for individual fixture drains; this size is used for building drains and stacks.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, tests and services interior drainage, waste and vent (DWV) systems
questions.subtask: C-10.01 Plans layout and sizes piping for DWV systems
questions.question: What is an island vent?

options.A: Special venting method for fixtures not adjacent to walls, looping above fixture flood rim

explanations.A: Island vents loop up from fixtures in counters or islands, rising above the flood rim before dropping to connect to venting.
explanations.B: Island vents are specific plumbing configurations for fixtures in islands and peninsulas, not geographic references.
explanations.C: Island vents are drainage venting pipe configurations, not mechanical exhaust equipment.
explanations.D: Island vents are code-approved solutions for venting fixtures installed away from walls in islands and peninsulas.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, tests and services interior drainage, waste and vent (DWV) systems
questions.subtask: C-10.02 Installs underground piping for DWV systems
questions.question: What precaution is necessary when installing drainage pipe in areas subject to ground settlement?

options.A: Use flexible couplings or joints to accommodate movement

explanations.A: Flexible joints accommodate differential settlement preventing joint separation and pipe breakage in unstable soils.
explanations.B: Rigid connections in settling areas will separate or break; flexibility is needed to accommodate movement.
explanations.C: Settlement occurs in many soil conditions and can damage rigid piping systems without proper accommodation.
explanations.D: Settlement-prone areas require specific measures including flexible joints to prevent damage from differential movement.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, tests and services interior drainage, waste and vent (DWV) systems
questions.subtask: C-10.02 Installs underground piping for DWV systems
questions.question: Why should clean-outs in underground drainage be extended to grade?

options.A: To provide access without excavation for clearing blockages

explanations.A: Grade-level clean-outs allow rodding and cleaning without excavation, reducing maintenance cost and disruption.
explanations.B: Underground clean-outs are functional, not decorative; accessible location enables efficient maintenance.
explanations.C: Buried clean-outs require excavation for access; grade extension is cost-effective for long-term maintenance.
explanations.D: The purpose of extending clean-outs is facilitating access; proper design reduces difficulty and cost of maintenance.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, tests and services interior drainage, waste and vent (DWV) systems
questions.subtask: C-10.02 Installs underground piping for DWV systems
questions.question: What is the purpose of a backwater valve in underground drainage?

options.A: To prevent sewage backup from municipal sewers during surcharge conditions

explanations.A: Backwater valves automatically close when sewer backs up, preventing reverse flow into building drains below sewer level.
explanations.B: Backwater valves prevent reverse flow; they do not increase forward flow velocity in normal drainage conditions.
explanations.C: Backwater valves protect buildings from sewer surcharges; they are critical in areas prone to backup conditions.
explanations.D: Backwater valves are one-way check valves preventing backflow, not storage devices for sewage.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, tests and services interior drainage, waste and vent (DWV) systems
questions.subtask: C-10.02 Installs underground piping for DWV systems
questions.question: How should underground drainage pipes be joined to prevent root intrusion?

options.A: Loose-fitting joints
options.B: Properly sealed joints using gaskets or solvent cement as appropriate

explanations.A: Loose joints invite root intrusion; proper sealing prevents root penetration and groundwater infiltration.
explanations.B: Properly sealed joints using appropriate methods prevent root intrusion and maintain system integrity.
explanations.C: Tape alone provides inadequate sealing; proper gaskets or cement create root-resistant, leak-tight joints.
explanations.D: Proper joints are essential for creating continuous sealed piping preventing infiltration and root entry.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, tests and services interior drainage, waste and vent (DWV) systems
questions.subtask: C-10.02 Installs underground piping for DWV systems
questions.question: What is the minimum cover depth for underground drainage piping to prevent freezing?

options.A: Depends on local frost depth and climate conditions

explanations.A: Minimum cover must exceed local frost penetration depth which varies by climate; codes specify local requirements.
explanations.B: While 300 mm may be adequate in mild climates, colder regions require much greater depth below frost line.
explanations.C: Adequate depth below frost line is essential to prevent freezing and ice blockages in drainage systems.
explanations.D: 10 meters is excessive for frost protection; typical depths are 0.6-1.5 meters depending on climate.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, tests and services interior drainage, waste and vent (DWV) systems
questions.subtask: C-10.02 Installs underground piping for DWV systems
questions.question: Why must underground drainage installation be inspected before backfilling?

options.A: To verify proper grade, alignment, and joint integrity while accessible

explanations.A: Pre-backfill inspection verifies code compliance while defects can be efficiently corrected; buried problems are costly.
explanations.B: Mandatory inspection prevents burying defects that would require expensive excavation to correct later.
explanations.C: Inspection verifies functional compliance; underground installations are not visible for aesthetic purposes.
explanations.D: Inspection is necessary quality assurance preventing failures; it protects investment rather than causing delays.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, tests and services interior drainage, waste and vent (DWV) systems
questions.subtask: C-10.02 Installs underground piping for DWV systems
questions.question: What material should not be used for backfill around drainage pipes?

options.A: Rocks larger than 50 mm, frozen material, or construction debris

explanations.A: Large rocks, frozen soil, and debris create point loads or voids that damage pipe; proper granular material is required.
explanations.B: Clean sand is acceptable backfill material providing uniform support without damaging point loads.
explanations.C: Crushed stone is acceptable backfill providing good support and drainage when properly sized and placed.
explanations.D: Material selection is critical; improper backfill causes pipe damage through point loads or settlement.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, tests and services interior drainage, waste and vent (DWV) systems
questions.subtask: C-10.03 Installs above-ground piping for DWV systems
questions.question: Why must horizontal drainage pipes be installed with uniform slope?

options.A: To prevent bellies where solids accumulate and maintain proper flow velocity

explanations.A: Uniform slope maintains consistent velocity preventing solids deposition; bellies and high spots cause accumulation and blockages.
explanations.B: Slope uniformity is critical for proper drainage; variations create problematic low spots and flow irregularities.
explanations.C: Uniform slope ensures proper hydraulic function; drainage system performance, not appearance, is the concern.
explanations.D: Inconsistent slope creates bellies and flow problems; uniform grade throughout the run is required for proper function.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, tests and services interior drainage, waste and vent (DWV) systems
questions.subtask: C-10.03 Installs above-ground piping for DWV systems
questions.question: What is the purpose of increasers in drainage systems?

options.A: To transition from smaller to larger pipe sizes maintaining smooth flow

explanations.A: Increasers create smooth transitions to larger sizes as flow accumulates, maintaining proper velocity and preventing turbulence.
explanations.B: Size reduction in drainage uses reducers; increasers enlarge diameter as required by increasing downstream loads.
explanations.C: Increasers are standard fittings for enlarging drainage pipes as additional fixtures add to cumulative flow.
explanations.D: Increasers are used in drainage systems; water supply uses different fittings appropriate for pressure systems.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, tests and services interior drainage, waste and vent (DWV) systems
questions.subtask: C-10.03 Installs above-ground piping for DWV systems
questions.question: Why should branch connections to horizontal drains enter from above or the side?

options.A: To prevent backup into branch and maintain smooth flow confluence

explanations.A: Above or side entries prevent backup into branches during high flows and create smoother confluence with main flow.
explanations.B: Bottom entries (inverts) create turbulence and backup risks; top or side entries provide better hydraulic performance.
explanations.C: Entry angle significantly affects flow patterns; proper orientation prevents backup and maintains efficient drainage.
explanations.D: The goal is smooth confluence minimizing turbulence; proper entry angle improves flow characteristics.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, tests and services interior drainage, waste and vent (DWV) systems
questions.subtask: C-10.03 Installs above-ground piping for DWV systems
questions.question: What is a sanitary tee and where is it used?

options.A: A drainage fitting with curved branch entry for horizontal to vertical flow transitions

explanations.A: Sanitary tees have swept branches allowing smooth flow from horizontal branches into vertical stacks without turbulence.
explanations.B: Sanitary tees are specific to drainage systems; water supply uses different straight-pattern tees.
explanations.C: While sanitary tees may provide clean-out access, they are branch fittings for connecting horizontal drains to vertical stacks.
explanations.D: Sanitary tees are standard drainage fittings specifically designed for horizontal-to-vertical flow transitions.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, tests and services interior drainage, waste and vent (DWV) systems
questions.subtask: C-10.03 Installs above-ground piping for DWV systems
questions.question: Why must drainage stacks have adequate clearance from combustible materials?

options.A: Hot drainage water could ignite materials if clearances are inadequate

explanations.A: While rare, very hot drainage from commercial equipment could ignite combustibles; codes specify clearances or protection.
explanations.B: Code-specified clearances or protection prevent fire hazards from hot drainage in certain applications.
explanations.C: Clearances serve fire safety purposes; they are code requirements preventing ignition, not arbitrary space waste.
explanations.D: While typical residential drainage is cool, commercial applications can discharge very hot water requiring protection.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, tests and services interior drainage, waste and vent (DWV) systems
questions.subtask: C-10.03 Installs above-ground piping for DWV systems
questions.question: What type of coupling should be used for repairing drainage piping?

options.A: No-hub couplings or approved repair couplings suitable for the pipe material

explanations.A: No-hub or material-specific repair couplings create code-compliant permanent leak-tight repairs.
explanations.B: Wire ties cannot create sealed pressure-tight joints required for drainage systems; proper couplings are necessary.
explanations.C: Rope cannot create sanitary sealed joints; approved mechanical or solvent-welded couplings are required.
explanations.D: Repairs are permitted using approved methods and materials creating permanent code-compliant connections.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, tests and services interior drainage, waste and vent (DWV) systems
questions.subtask: C-10.03 Installs above-ground piping for DWV systems
questions.question: Why should drainage pipes not be supported by hangers at joints?

options.A: Joint weight creates stress risking separation; supports should be on pipe body

explanations.A: Supporting at joints concentrates stress at connections; supports on pipe body distribute loads preventing joint strain.
explanations.B: Joint support is avoided; placing supports on solid pipe sections prevents joint stress and potential separation.
explanations.C: Support location significantly affects joint integrity; proper placement on pipe body prevents joint failures.
explanations.D: Joints are stress concentration points, not reinforced areas; supports belong on solid pipe sections.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, tests and services interior drainage, waste and vent (DWV) systems
questions.subtask: C-10.03 Installs above-ground piping for DWV systems
questions.question: What is a vent terminal and why must it extend above the roof?

options.A: The open end of vent piping extending above roof to discharge gases and admit air

explanations.A: Vent terminals extend above roofs allowing safe gas discharge away from windows and providing atmospheric air entry.
explanations.B: Vent terminals serve critical functional purposes discharging sewer gases and providing system ventilation.
explanations.C: Vent terminals discharge air and gases, not water; they are air passages for drainage system venting.
explanations.D: Vent terminals are essential for proper system venting; they must extend above roofs per code requirements.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, tests and services interior drainage, waste and vent (DWV) systems
questions.subtask: C-10.03 Installs above-ground piping for DWV systems
questions.question: Why must horizontal offsets in drainage stacks be properly vented?

options.A: Offsets create pressure changes requiring additional venting to maintain system balance

explanations.A: Stack offsets disrupt flow patterns creating pressure variations; proper venting at offsets maintains system equilibrium.
explanations.B: Offsets require special venting consideration; pressure changes at offsets can affect trap seals without proper venting.
explanations.C: Offset venting serves functional purposes maintaining proper pressure balance; performance, not appearance, is the concern.
explanations.D: Offset venting requirements ensure proper system function; they are engineering necessities, not arbitrary complications.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, tests and services interior drainage, waste and vent (DWV) systems
questions.subtask: C-10.04 Tests DWV systems
questions.question: What is the typical duration for a drainage system air test?

options.A: 5 seconds
options.D: Air tests have no time requirement

explanations.A: 5 seconds is insufficient to detect slow leaks; adequate test duration allows small leaks to become apparent.
explanations.B: Most codes require minimum 15-minute air test duration to verify system integrity and detect leaks.
explanations.C: 24 hours is excessive for standard testing; 15 minutes to several hours depending on system size is typical.
explanations.D: Specific test duration is required to ensure adequate verification of system integrity; time is a critical parameter.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, tests and services interior drainage, waste and vent (DWV) systems
questions.subtask: C-10.04 Tests DWV systems
questions.question: Why should all fixtures have their traps filled before final system testing?

options.A: To verify trap seals hold and prevent air escape through drains during testing
options.B: Empty traps work better for testing
options.D: To add weight to the system

explanations.A: Filled traps seal the system for testing; empty traps allow air escape making pressure testing impossible.
explanations.B: Empty traps defeat testing by allowing air escape through open drains; seals must be in place to test system integrity.
explanations.C: Trap filling is essential for pressure testing; traps seal the system allowing pressure verification.
explanations.D: Water in traps serves as a seal for testing, not as ballast; the purpose is creating a closed system for pressure testing.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, tests and services interior drainage, waste and vent (DWV) systems
questions.subtask: C-10.04 Tests DWV systems
questions.question: What equipment is needed to perform an air test on a DWV system?

options.A: Air compressor, pressure gauge, test plugs, and timing device

explanations.A: Air testing requires air source, pressure measurement, system sealing (plugs), and timing to monitor pressure retention.
explanations.B: Proper air testing requires specific equipment to pressurize, seal, measure, and monitor the system.
explanations.C: Water hoses are for water testing; air testing requires compressed air source and pressure monitoring equipment.
explanations.D: Hammers are not testing equipment; proper air testing requires pressurization and measurement apparatus.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, tests and services interior drainage, waste and vent (DWV) systems
questions.subtask: C-10.04 Tests DWV systems
questions.question: Where should test plugs be installed for drainage system testing?

options.A: At all open terminations including building drain outlet and vent terminals

explanations.A: All openings must be plugged to create a sealed system for pressure testing; any unplugged opening prevents testing.
explanations.B: Test plugs are essential for sealing the system to allow pressure or water testing of integrity.
explanations.C: Single-point plugging leaves other openings unsealed preventing system pressurization; all openings require plugging.
explanations.D: Systematic plugging of all openings is required, not random placement; complete sealing enables effective testing.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, tests and services interior drainage, waste and vent (DWV) systems
questions.subtask: C-10.04 Tests DWV systems
questions.question: What indicates a failed air test?

options.A: Pressure drop exceeding specifications during the test period

explanations.A: Pressure loss beyond allowable limits indicates leaks requiring repair; the system must maintain specified pressure.
explanations.B: Maintaining pressure indicates passing the test; pressure stability shows leak-tight system integrity.
explanations.C: Pressure increase would indicate improper testing setup; normal testing monitors for pressure decay indicating leaks.
explanations.D: Test failures occur when leaks are present; failed tests require locating and repairing leaks before retesting.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, tests and services interior drainage, waste and vent (DWV) systems
questions.subtask: C-10.04 Tests DWV systems
questions.question: Why is it important to document test results?

options.A: To provide code compliance proof, warranty documentation, and future reference

explanations.A: Test documentation proves code compliance, supports warranties, and provides reference for future modifications or troubleshooting.
explanations.B: Documentation is required for code compliance verification and provides important records for warranty and future work.
explanations.C: Test documentation serves critical legal and technical purposes; it is not an aesthetic consideration.
explanations.D: Documentation protects all parties and provides valuable records; it is essential professional practice, not waste.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, tests and services interior drainage, waste and vent (DWV) systems
questions.subtask: C-10.04 Tests DWV systems
questions.question: Can portions of a large DWV system be tested separately?

options.A: Yes, sections can be tested as work progresses if properly isolated
options.B: No, only complete system testing is permitted

explanations.A: Sectional testing is acceptable and practical for large systems; proper plugging isolates sections for independent verification.
explanations.B: While complete testing is ideal, codes permit sectional testing for large or phased projects when properly executed.
explanations.C: Testing is required for code compliance; both complete and properly executed sectional testing are acceptable methods.
explanations.D: Test plugs allow isolation of sections for independent testing; sectional testing is common practice in large installations.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, tests and services interior drainage, waste and vent (DWV) systems
questions.subtask: C-10.04 Tests DWV systems
questions.question: What must be done if a water test cannot be performed on a drainage system?

options.A: Use alternative approved test methods like air testing
options.D: Water testing is the only option

explanations.A: When water testing is impractical, approved alternatives like air testing provide equivalent verification of system integrity.
explanations.B: Some form of testing is required for code compliance; if water testing is impractical, approved alternatives must be used.
explanations.C: Testing provides objective verification of system integrity; assumptions are inadequate for code compliance.
explanations.D: Multiple approved test methods exist including air and smoke testing; water testing is one of several acceptable methods.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, tests and services interior drainage, waste and vent (DWV) systems
questions.subtask: C-10.05 Services DWV systems
questions.question: What is the most effective method for preventing grease blockages in kitchen drains?

options.A: Installing grease traps and educating users on proper disposal

explanations.A: Grease traps capture fats before drain entry, while proper disposal education prevents grease from entering drainage systems.
explanations.B: Hot water temporarily liquefies grease but it resolidifies in pipes; proper disposal and trapping are necessary.
explanations.C: Daily chemical use is harmful to pipes and environment; grease prevention through trapping and proper disposal is appropriate.
explanations.D: Grease blockages are preventable through source control, proper disposal, and grease trap installation.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, tests and services interior drainage, waste and vent (DWV) systems
questions.subtask: C-10.05 Services DWV systems
questions.question: How often should commercial grease traps be cleaned?

options.A: Based on grease accumulation, typically weekly to monthly depending on use

explanations.A: Cleaning frequency depends on grease loading; traps should be cleaned when 25% full to maintain capacity.
explanations.B: Grease traps accumulate material continuously and require regular cleaning to maintain function and prevent overflow.
explanations.C: Decade-long intervals allow complete filling and failure; commercial traps typically need weekly or monthly cleaning.
explanations.D: While high-volume operations may need frequent cleaning, daily service is typically unnecessary for most applications.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, tests and services interior drainage, waste and vent (DWV) systems
questions.subtask: C-10.05 Services DWV systems
questions.question: What causes slow draining in multiple fixtures on the same floor?

options.A: Partial blockage in the common horizontal drain or vent obstruction

explanations.A: Multiple fixture problems indicate shared drain blockage or vent restriction affecting all connected fixtures.
explanations.B: Slow drainage indicates problems requiring attention; multiple fixtures affected points to common drain or vent issues.
explanations.C: Water pressure relates to supply systems; drainage is gravity-driven and slow drainage indicates obstructions or vent problems.
explanations.D: When multiple fixtures drain slowly, the problem is in shared drainage or venting, not individual fixture components.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, tests and services interior drainage, waste and vent (DWV) systems
questions.subtask: C-10.05 Services DWV systems
questions.question: What should be checked when a trap seal is repeatedly lost?

options.A: Venting adequacy, fixture usage frequency, and potential siphonage or evaporation

explanations.A: Seal loss indicates venting problems causing siphonage, evaporation in unused fixtures, or capillary action requiring correction.
explanations.B: Trap seal loss has identifiable causes that can be corrected through venting improvements, regular use, or seal protection.
explanations.C: Fixture color is unrelated to trap seal mechanics; venting, use, and evaporation are the relevant factors.
explanations.D: Trap seals should remain filled; repeated loss indicates problems requiring investigation and correction.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, tests and services interior drainage, waste and vent (DWV) systems
questions.subtask: C-10.05 Services DWV systems
questions.question: Why should vent pipes not be capped or sealed?

options.A: Sealing vents prevents air circulation causing drainage problems and trap seal loss

explanations.A: Open vents are essential for system function; sealing prevents air circulation causing slow drainage and trap siphonage.
explanations.B: Sealed vents cause system malfunction; open vents are required for proper pressure equalization and drainage.
explanations.C: Vents must allow air entry to maintain atmospheric pressure; preventing air entry defeats their essential purpose.
explanations.D: Vents must remain open to atmosphere; sealing causes drainage system malfunction and code violations.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, tests and services interior drainage, waste and vent (DWV) systems
questions.subtask: C-10.05 Services DWV systems
questions.question: What maintenance is required for floor drain trap primers?

options.A: Regular inspection and testing to ensure they deliver water maintaining trap seals

explanations.A: Trap primers require periodic inspection to verify operation, ensuring they maintain floor drain seals preventing gas entry.
explanations.B: Trap primers are mechanical devices requiring periodic verification to ensure proper function maintaining trap seals.
explanations.C: Trap primers serve important functions maintaining seals in infrequently used drains; they should be maintained, not removed.
explanations.D: Trap primers are common devices for maintaining seals in floor drains and other fixtures subject to evaporation.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, tests and services interior drainage, waste and vent (DWV) systems
questions.subtask: C-10.05 Services DWV systems
questions.question: How can frozen drainage pipes be thawed safely?

options.A: Apply gentle heat with electric heating tape or warm air, never open flame
options.B: Use blowtorches directly on plastic pipes

explanations.A: Gentle uniform heating with electric heating devices or warm air safely thaws pipes without damage or fire risk.
explanations.B: Open flames risk fire and can melt or damage plastic pipes; controlled electrical heating is safe and effective.
explanations.C: While natural thawing occurs eventually, service disruption and potential pipe damage from ice expansion warrant active thawing.
explanations.D: Mechanical force on frozen pipes causes breakage; thawing requires heat application, not impact.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, tests and services interior drainage, waste and vent (DWV) systems
questions.subtask: C-10.05 Services DWV systems
questions.question: What causes condensation on drainage pipes and how can it be addressed?

options.A: Temperature difference between pipe and ambient air; address with insulation

explanations.A: Cool drainage pipes in humid areas condense moisture; insulation prevents condensation by maintaining pipe surface above dew point.
explanations.B: Condensation causes water damage, mold growth, and deterioration; it should be prevented through proper insulation.
explanations.C: Condensation is preventable through insulation raising pipe surface temperature above ambient dew point.
explanations.D: Drainage pipes carrying cool water or sewage can condense moisture in humid conditions; condensation is a common problem.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, tests and services interior drainage, waste and vent (DWV) systems
questions.subtask: C-10.05 Services DWV systems
questions.question: Why should pop-up drain stoppers be cleaned regularly?

options.A: Hair and soap accumulate restricting drainage and creating odors

explanations.A: Hair and soap scum accumulate on pop-up mechanisms, restricting flow and creating odors requiring regular cleaning.
explanations.B: Pop-up assemblies accumulate debris continuously and require periodic cleaning to maintain function and prevent odors.
explanations.C: Regular cleaning maintains proper function; neglect causes progressive flow restriction and eventual complete blockage.
explanations.D: While appearance improves with cleaning, the critical reasons are maintaining flow and preventing odor-causing buildup.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, tests and services interior drainage, waste and vent (DWV) systems
questions.subtask: C-10.05 Services DWV systems
questions.question: What indicates a main sewer line blockage versus individual fixture problems?

options.A: Multiple fixtures throughout the building affected, especially lower level backups

explanations.A: Main line blockages affect multiple fixtures with lowest level backups appearing first as the system fills from the obstruction.
explanations.B: Single fixture problems typically indicate localized issues in that fixture's drain, not main line blockages.
explanations.C: Widespread drainage problems indicate main line blockage; perfect operation shows no blockage is present.
explanations.D: Main line blockages are common problems requiring professional clearing; they affect entire building drainage.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, tests and services interior drainage, waste and vent (DWV) systems
questions.subtask: C-10.05 Services DWV systems
questions.question: How can odors from basement floor drains be eliminated?

options.A: Add water to refill trap seals that have evaporated

explanations.A: Floor drain odors typically result from evaporated trap seals; adding water restores the seal blocking sewer gases.
explanations.B: Chemicals are temporary solutions that don't address the root cause of dry traps; water addition maintains proper seals.
explanations.C: Sealing floor drains eliminates their drainage function; maintaining trap seals through water addition is the proper solution.
explanations.D: Sewer gas odors indicate trap seal loss requiring correction; they are not acceptable and indicate maintenance needs.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, tests and services interior drainage, waste and vent (DWV) systems
questions.subtask: C-10.01 Plans layout and sizes piping for DWV systems
questions.question: What is the purpose of a loop vent?

options.A: To vent a series of fixtures on a horizontal branch

explanations.A: Loop vents rise from horizontal fixture branches connecting back to the stack, venting multiple fixtures efficiently.
explanations.B: Loop vents serve functional venting purposes for multiple fixtures; they are technical components, not decorative.
explanations.C: Loop vents are air passages providing pressure equalization, not water storage devices.
explanations.D: Loop vents are recognized code methods for efficiently venting multiple fixtures on horizontal branches.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, tests and services interior drainage, waste and vent (DWV) systems
questions.subtask: C-10.01 Plans layout and sizes piping for DWV systems
questions.question: Why must the building drain be sized larger than individual branch drains?

options.A: To accommodate cumulative flow from all branches connected upstream

explanations.A: Building drains carry cumulative discharge from all connected fixtures requiring sizing for total system load.
explanations.B: Underground building drains are not visible; sizing is functional requirement for adequate capacity, not appearance.
explanations.C: Building drains must be larger to carry cumulative flows; smaller sizes would create backups and system failure.
explanations.D: Proper sizing is critical for system function; undersized building drains cause backups throughout the system.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, tests and services interior drainage, waste and vent (DWV) systems
questions.subtask: C-10.01 Plans layout and sizes piping for DWV systems
questions.question: What is a yoke vent?

options.A: A pipe connecting an upward extension of a soil or waste stack to a vent stack

explanations.A: Yoke vents provide relief venting in tall stacks by connecting the drainage stack extension to separate vent stacks.
explanations.B: Yoke vents are plumbing components for pressure relief in tall stacks, not equipment support hardware.
explanations.C: Yoke vents are drainage system air pipes, not water supply components; they provide pressure equalization.
explanations.D: Yoke vents are code-recognized relief venting methods for multi-story buildings preventing pressure fluctuations.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, tests and services interior drainage, waste and vent (DWV) systems
questions.subtask: C-10.01 Plans layout and sizes piping for DWV systems
questions.question: Why should vent pipes not be less than half the diameter of the drain they serve?

options.A: To provide adequate air circulation capacity preventing trap seal loss
options.C: Vent size is unrelated to drain size
options.D: Vents should be smaller than drains

explanations.A: Adequate vent diameter ensures sufficient air circulation to prevent vacuum formation and maintain proper drainage function.
explanations.B: Undersized vents restrict air flow causing trap siphonage and slow drainage; adequate sizing is essential.
explanations.C: Vent sizing relates directly to drain size and flow; adequate proportion maintains proper pressure balance.
explanations.D: While vents can be smaller than drains, they must be adequate for air volume; minimum sizing ratios are specified.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, tests and services interior drainage, waste and vent (DWV) systems
questions.subtask: C-10.01 Plans layout and sizes piping for DWV systems
questions.question: What is the minimum diameter for a vent serving a water closet?

options.A: 32 mm (1.25 inches)

explanations.A: 32 mm is too small for toilet venting; larger diameter is required for adequate air circulation.
explanations.B: 38 mm is insufficient for water closet venting which requires larger diameter for proper air circulation.
explanations.C: Water closets typically require minimum 50 mm (2-inch) vents to provide adequate air circulation for large discharge volumes.
explanations.D: While 100 mm would work, it exceeds typical requirements; 50 mm is the standard minimum for individual toilet venting.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, tests and services interior drainage, waste and vent (DWV) systems
questions.subtask: C-10.01 Plans layout and sizes piping for DWV systems
questions.question: Why must drainage systems avoid S-traps?

options.A: S-traps are prone to self-siphonage without proper venting

explanations.A: S-traps lack venting between trap and drain connection allowing self-siphonage that depletes trap seals.
explanations.B: S-traps are prohibited because they inherently allow trap seal siphonage; they do not provide reliable gas blocking.
explanations.C: S-trap prohibition is based on functional problems causing seal loss; prevention improves system reliability.
explanations.D: Codes prohibit S-traps in new construction; proper P-traps with venting are required for reliable trap seal retention.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, tests and services interior drainage, waste and vent (DWV) systems
questions.subtask: C-10.02 Installs underground piping for DWV systems
questions.question: What is the purpose of a house trap where required?

options.A: To provide water seal preventing sewer gases from municipal sewer entering building

explanations.A: House traps create a barrier preventing sewer gases from public sewers entering building drainage systems.
explanations.B: House traps are flow-through water seals, not storage; they block gases while allowing waste passage.
explanations.C: House traps are passive water barriers and do not heat; they block gases through water column.
explanations.D: While not universally required, house traps are mandated in some jurisdictions to isolate building drainage from sewer gases.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, tests and services interior drainage, waste and vent (DWV) systems
questions.subtask: C-10.02 Installs underground piping for DWV systems
questions.question: Why should underground drainage pipes not have sharp bends?

options.A: Sharp bends create turbulence and solids accumulation causing blockages

explanations.A: Long-sweep fittings maintain flow velocity and reduce turbulence preventing solids deposition at direction changes.
explanations.B: Sharp bends disrupt flow and create stagnation zones where solids accumulate; gradual changes maintain flow.
explanations.C: Bend geometry significantly affects flow patterns; proper radius fittings prevent blockages and maintain velocity.
explanations.D: Codes require long-sweep fittings in drainage; sharp bends are prohibited due to flow disruption and blockage potential.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, tests and services interior drainage, waste and vent (DWV) systems
questions.subtask: C-10.02 Installs underground piping for DWV systems
questions.question: What precaution prevents settlement damage to underground drainage pipes?

options.A: Proper bedding, compacted backfill in layers, and potential flexible joints

explanations.A: Proper support through bedding and controlled backfill prevents settlement; flexible joints accommodate remaining movement.
explanations.B: Settlement precautions are essential for preventing pipe breakage and joint separation in underground installations.
explanations.C: Loose backfill causes uncontrolled settlement; proper compaction in layers prevents excessive differential settlement.
explanations.D: While complete prevention is impossible, proper installation minimizes settlement and accommodates unavoidable movement.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, tests and services interior drainage, waste and vent (DWV) systems
questions.subtask: C-10.03 Installs above-ground piping for DWV systems
questions.question: Why must drainage pipes through exterior walls be protected from freezing?

options.A: Frozen water expands causing pipe rupture and ice blockages

explanations.A: Water freezing in pipes expands causing rupture; ice blockages prevent drainage requiring thawing or replacement.
explanations.B: Freezing causes catastrophic pipe damage and complete flow blockage; protection is essential in cold climates.
explanations.C: Exterior wall penetrations in freezing climates require insulation or heat tracing to prevent destructive freezing.
explanations.D: Drainage pipes contain water and are vulnerable to freezing; protection is necessary in exterior walls in cold climates.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, tests and services interior drainage, waste and vent (DWV) systems
questions.subtask: C-10.03 Installs above-ground piping for DWV systems
questions.question: What is the purpose of a drum trap and why are they generally prohibited?

options.A: Drum traps are difficult to clean and prone to clogging; modern P-traps are superior
options.B: Drum traps are required by modern codes

explanations.A: Drum traps' horizontal orientation makes cleaning difficult; they accumulate debris and are prohibited in favor of P-traps.
explanations.B: Modern codes prohibit drum traps in new installations; P-traps with cleanout access are required for maintainability.
explanations.C: Drum traps actually impede maintenance and accumulate debris; P-traps provide better flow and cleaning access.
explanations.D: Drum traps have significant maintenance problems; their prohibition reflects superior performance of modern P-trap designs.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, tests and services interior drainage, waste and vent (DWV) systems
questions.subtask: C-10.03 Installs above-ground piping for DWV systems
questions.question: Why should horizontal drainage pipes be supported at proper intervals?

options.A: To prevent sagging that creates bellies and low spots collecting solids

explanations.A: Adequate support prevents sagging that creates low spots where water and solids accumulate causing blockages.
explanations.B: Support spacing is critical for maintaining designed slope; excessive spacing allows sagging and belly formation.
explanations.C: Proper support maintains hydraulic function through consistent grade; performance, not appearance, is the concern.
explanations.D: Drainage pipes require support to prevent deflection from pipe weight and contents; unsupported spans will sag.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, tests and services interior drainage, waste and vent (DWV) systems
questions.subtask: C-10.03 Installs above-ground piping for DWV systems
questions.question: What type of fitting should be used for cleanout access in drainage systems?

options.A: Wye or combination wye and eighth bend with removable plug

explanations.A: Wye fittings allow cleaning cables to enter in the direction of flow preventing equipment damage and ensuring effective clearing.
explanations.B: Horizontal sanitary tees create cable entry at wrong angle for effective clearing; wyes align with flow direction.
explanations.C: Standard elbows without cleanout provisions don't provide proper access for clearing blockages.
explanations.D: Cleanouts are required at specified locations; proper fittings enable access for clearing blockages.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, tests and services interior drainage, waste and vent (DWV) systems
questions.subtask: C-10.03 Installs above-ground piping for DWV systems
questions.question: Why must vent terminals be protected from bird and insect entry?

options.A: Nests and blockages can obstruct vents impairing drainage system function

explanations.A: Birds, insects, and debris can block vent terminals preventing air circulation and causing drainage problems.
explanations.B: Vent protection prevents blockages that impair system function; screens or cowls maintain vent function.
explanations.C: Bird nests block vents causing drainage malfunction; protection maintains proper air circulation.
explanations.D: Vent protection serves functional purposes preventing blockages; system performance, not appearance, is the concern.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, tests and services interior drainage, waste and vent (DWV) systems
questions.subtask: C-10.04 Tests DWV systems
questions.question: What is the standard water column height for testing a building drain?

options.A: Varies by code, typically 3 meters (10 feet) or filling to lowest fixture

explanations.A: Test head varies by jurisdiction; typical requirement is 3-meter head or filling to lowest fixture level.
explanations.B: Specific test pressure or head is required to adequately stress the system revealing leaks.
explanations.C: 100 meters would create excessive pressure potentially damaging systems; typical heads are 3-10 meters.
explanations.D: Test head is specified in codes to ensure adequate stress; specific heights are required for standardized testing.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, tests and services interior drainage, waste and vent (DWV) systems
questions.subtask: C-10.04 Tests DWV systems
questions.question: Why should testing be performed in sections for large systems?

options.A: To identify leak locations more easily and test as work progresses

explanations.A: Sectional testing allows progressive verification isolating problems to specific areas facilitating efficient correction.
explanations.B: Sectional testing is accepted practice for large systems; proper isolation allows phased testing as work progresses.
explanations.C: Sectional testing improves efficiency by testing completed sections without waiting for entire system completion.
