explanations.D: Large systems require testing; sectional approach makes testing manageable and identifies problems efficiently.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, tests and services interior drainage, waste and vent (DWV) systems
questions.subtask: C-10.04 Tests DWV systems
questions.question: What visual inspection should be performed before pressure testing?

options.A: Verify all joints properly made, supports installed, and no obvious defects

explanations.A: Visual inspection identifies obvious defects before testing, avoiding test failures from easily observed problems.
explanations.B: Visual inspection prevents wasting time testing obviously defective installations; it is essential preliminary step.
explanations.C: Pipe identification is one factor; comprehensive visual inspection verifies joints, supports, and overall installation quality.
explanations.D: Visual inspection catches obvious defects before formal testing, saving time and ensuring only quality work proceeds to testing.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, tests and services interior drainage, waste and vent (DWV) systems
questions.subtask: C-10.04 Tests DWV systems
questions.question: What should be done if a test reveals leaks?

options.A: Locate leaks, make repairs, and retest until system passes
options.C: Test is complete regardless of leaks

explanations.A: Failed tests require leak location, proper repairs, and retesting until system meets acceptance criteria.
explanations.B: Leaks must be corrected before system acceptance; ignoring them leads to failures and code violations.
explanations.C: Systems must pass testing before acceptance; leaks indicate defects requiring correction before burial or enclosure.
explanations.D: Concealing defects without repair creates future problems; proper correction and retesting are required.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, tests and services interior drainage, waste and vent (DWV) systems
questions.subtask: C-10.05 Services DWV systems
questions.question: What causes sewer gas odors in buildings?

options.A: Lost trap seals, vent obstructions, or system leaks allowing gas entry

explanations.A: Sewer gas entry results from dried trap seals, blocked vents, or leaks bypassing water seals.
explanations.B: Proper systems block sewer gases; odors indicate trap seal loss, vent problems, or leaks requiring correction.
explanations.C: Fresh air comes through vents above roofs; sewer gas odors indicate trap or system failures allowing contamination.
explanations.D: Sewer gases contain toxic and odorous compounds; their presence indicates system problems requiring attention.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, tests and services interior drainage, waste and vent (DWV) systems
questions.subtask: C-10.05 Services DWV systems
questions.question: How should hair accumulation in drains be prevented?

options.A: Use drain screens or strainers catching hair before it enters piping

explanations.A: Drain screens catch hair before it enters piping where it combines with soap forming stubborn blockages.
explanations.B: Hair accumulation is controllable through screens preventing entry and regular cleaning of caught material.
explanations.C: Hair is a primary blockage cause; prevention through screening and regular cleaning maintains proper drainage.
explanations.D: Chemicals don't prevent accumulation and damage pipes; physical barriers and regular cleaning are appropriate prevention.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, tests and services interior drainage, waste and vent (DWV) systems
questions.subtask: C-10.05 Services DWV systems
questions.question: What maintenance extends drainage system life?

options.A: Regular cleaning, proper use, avoiding inappropriate disposals, and prompt problem correction

explanations.A: Regular maintenance, proper waste disposal, and addressing problems promptly prevent major failures extending system life.
explanations.B: Neglect causes progressive deterioration and failures; regular attention maintains function and extends service life.
explanations.C: Improper disposal is the primary cause of drain problems; proper use prevents most maintenance issues.
explanations.D: Addressing problems early prevents escalation to major failures; prompt attention is essential maintenance practice.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, tests and services interior drainage, waste and vent (DWV) systems
questions.subtask: C-10.05 Services DWV systems
questions.question: Why should professional video inspection be considered for old drainage systems?

options.A: To assess pipe condition, identify problems, and plan preventive repairs

explanations.A: Video inspection reveals interior condition, identifies developing problems, and enables proactive maintenance preventing failures.
explanations.B: Video inspection is valuable diagnostic tool providing interior views impossible through other methods.
explanations.C: Video inspection is professional diagnostic service documenting condition and identifying problems requiring attention.
explanations.D: Old systems particularly benefit from inspection revealing deterioration before catastrophic failures occur.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, tests and services interior drainage, waste and vent (DWV) systems
questions.subtask: C-10.01 Plans layout and sizes piping for DWV systems
questions.question: What is horizontal branch interval in drainage systems?

options.A: Vertical distance of one story height, approximately 2.4-3 meters (8-10 feet)

explanations.A: Branch intervals represent vertical story heights used in calculating stack loading and sizing drainage systems.
explanations.B: Branch intervals measure vertical stack divisions, not horizontal distances; they represent story height increments.
explanations.C: Branch intervals are physical vertical measurements, not time-based usage intervals.
explanations.D: Branch intervals are standard vertical measurements used in drainage system design and stack sizing calculations.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, tests and services interior drainage, waste and vent (DWV) systems
questions.subtask: C-10.01 Plans layout and sizes piping for DWV systems
questions.question: Why must fixture drains connect to stacks with proper fittings?

options.A: To maintain smooth flow transition and prevent turbulence causing siphonage

explanations.A: Proper fittings with sweep patterns maintain flow and prevent turbulence that could siphon trap seals.
explanations.B: Fitting geometry significantly affects flow patterns and trap seal protection; proper types are code-required.
explanations.C: Improper fittings create turbulence and pressure problems affecting trap seals; specified fittings ensure proper function.
explanations.D: Fitting requirements ensure proper hydraulic performance; they are engineering specifications, not arbitrary complications.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, tests and services interior drainage, waste and vent (DWV) systems
questions.subtask: C-10.01 Plans layout and sizes piping for DWV systems
questions.question: What is a stack vent in relation to a vent stack?

options.A: Extension of soil or waste stack above highest fixture; vent stack is separate pipe

explanations.A: Stack vents extend drainage stacks above fixtures; vent stacks are dedicated vent pipes connected to drainage stacks.
explanations.B: While related, stack vents extend drainage stacks while vent stacks are separate dedicated vent piping.
explanations.C: Stack vents are essential components extending drainage stacks to atmosphere for system venting.
explanations.D: Stack vents serve critical venting functions providing atmospheric connection; they are not decorative elements.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, tests and services interior drainage, waste and vent (DWV) systems
questions.subtask: C-10.01 Plans layout and sizes piping for DWV systems
questions.question: Why are fixture unit values assigned to different fixtures?

options.A: To standardize load calculations for drainage and vent sizing

explanations.A: Fixture units provide standardized method for calculating cumulative loads and sizing drainage and venting systems.
explanations.B: Fixture units are technical values for engineering calculations, not decorative or arbitrary assignments.
explanations.C: Fixture units are fundamental to drainage system design providing standardized load values for sizing calculations.
explanations.D: Fixture units simplify complex flow calculations into manageable design values; they clarify rather than confuse design.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, tests and services interior drainage, waste and vent (DWV) systems
questions.subtask: C-10.02 Installs underground piping for DWV systems
questions.question: What is the purpose of a running trap and why are they generally prohibited?

options.A: Running traps restrict flow and complicate cleaning; modern systems use other methods

explanations.A: Running traps in building drains restrict flow and accumulate debris; modern venting methods are superior.
explanations.B: Running traps are generally prohibited in modern codes; alternative designs provide better function.
explanations.C: Running traps impede flow and accumulate material; they create more problems than benefits.
explanations.D: Running traps cause maintenance problems through flow restriction and debris accumulation; modern designs avoid them.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, tests and services interior drainage, waste and vent (DWV) systems
questions.subtask: C-10.02 Installs underground piping for DWV systems
questions.question: How should underground drainage connect to a septic system?

options.A: With properly sized piping at correct elevation maintaining minimum slope
options.D: Underground drainage should not connect to septic

explanations.A: Proper sizing, elevation, and slope ensure adequate flow to septic tank while preventing backup.
explanations.B: Random connections without proper slope and sizing cause flow problems and system malfunction.
explanations.C: Building drainage must connect to sewage disposal system; proper connection is essential for function.
explanations.D: Underground building drains connect to septic systems where municipal sewers are unavailable; proper connection is essential.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, tests and services interior drainage, waste and vent (DWV) systems
questions.subtask: C-10.02 Installs underground piping for DWV systems
questions.question: Why should clean-out covers in floors be accessible and properly sealed?

options.A: To enable maintenance access while preventing odors and debris entry

explanations.A: Accessible covers enable maintenance while proper sealing prevents sewer gas escape and debris entry to clean-outs.
explanations.B: Sealing prevents sewer gas odors and contamination; accessible sealed covers balance maintenance needs with odor control.
explanations.C: While appearance is affected, the critical reasons are maintenance access and preventing gas escape.
explanations.D: Clean-out covers are required for sealing access points; they prevent gas escape while enabling maintenance.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, tests and services interior drainage, waste and vent (DWV) systems
questions.subtask: C-10.03 Installs above-ground piping for DWV systems
questions.question: What is the purpose of an auto vent or sure vent?

options.A: Mechanical device allowing air entry while preventing gas escape as alternative to conventional venting

explanations.A: Auto vents (AAVs) allow air into drainage preventing vacuum while sealing against gas escape when not needed.
explanations.B: Auto vents are drainage venting devices, not heating equipment; they provide mechanical venting function.
explanations.C: Auto vents control air flow for drainage venting, not water flow; they are venting alternatives.
explanations.D: Auto vents are code-approved in many jurisdictions for specific applications where conventional venting is impractical.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, tests and services interior drainage, waste and vent (DWV) systems
questions.subtask: C-10.03 Installs above-ground piping for DWV systems
questions.question: Why should drainage piping avoid horizontal runs with insufficient slope?

options.A: Insufficient slope allows solids settling creating blockages and flow problems

explanations.A: Adequate slope maintains velocity to transport solids; insufficient slope allows settlement causing blockages.
explanations.B: Slope is critical for gravity drainage; inadequate slope prevents proper solids transport causing accumulation.
explanations.C: Level pipes allow complete solids settling causing rapid blockage; minimum slope is essential for proper drainage.
explanations.D: Minimum code-specified slopes are required to maintain adequate flow velocity; insufficient slope causes problems.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, tests and services interior drainage, waste and vent (DWV) systems
questions.subtask: C-10.03 Installs above-ground piping for DWV systems
questions.question: What consideration is needed when routing drainage near electrical panels?

options.A: Maintain separation or protection preventing leaks from damaging electrical equipment

explanations.A: Drainage must be separated from electrical equipment or protected to prevent leaks causing electrical hazards.
explanations.B: Routing through electrical panels creates serious safety hazards; separation or protection is required.
explanations.C: Drainage leaks near electrical equipment create electrocution and fire hazards; code requires separation or protection.
explanations.D: Drainage near electrical creates hazards if leaks occur; proper separation protects safety.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, tests and services interior drainage, waste and vent (DWV) systems
questions.subtask: C-10.03 Installs above-ground piping for DWV systems
questions.question: Why must fixture trap arms maintain proper slope?

options.A: To ensure self-cleaning flow preventing accumulation while avoiding excessive velocity causing siphonage
options.B: Slope is unimportant for trap arms

explanations.A: Proper slope maintains self-cleaning velocity without excessive speed that would siphon trap seals.
explanations.B: Trap arm slope is critical for self-cleaning action and preventing trap seal siphonage; proper slope is essential.
explanations.C: Level trap arms accumulate debris and may not drain properly; minimum slope is required for self-cleaning.
explanations.D: Trap arms are concealed; slope ensures proper drainage function and trap seal protection, not appearance.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, tests and services interior drainage, waste and vent (DWV) systems
questions.subtask: C-10.04 Tests DWV systems
questions.question: What safety precautions are necessary when performing water tests?

options.A: Ensure structure can support water weight and personnel safety during filling and observation

explanations.A: Water weight is significant; structure must support test loads and personnel must have safe access during filling and inspection.
explanations.B: Water testing creates significant loads and requires safe access; proper safety procedures protect personnel and structure.
explanations.C: Controlled filling allows monitoring for leaks during filling and prevents sudden structural loading; gradual filling is appropriate.
explanations.D: Safety is paramount in all construction activities; water testing requires specific precautions protecting workers and structures.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, tests and services interior drainage, waste and vent (DWV) systems
questions.subtask: C-10.04 Tests DWV systems
questions.question: Why should test equipment be properly calibrated?

options.A: To ensure accurate pressure measurements and valid test results

explanations.A: Accurate instrumentation ensures test results are valid and reliable for code compliance verification.
explanations.B: Calibrated equipment ensures test validity; inaccurate measurements could pass defective systems or fail acceptable ones.
explanations.C: Gauge accuracy varies; calibrated equipment ensures measurements meet specified test criteria accurately.
explanations.D: Test accuracy is essential for code compliance verification; proper equipment ensures meaningful results.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, tests and services interior drainage, waste and vent (DWV) systems
questions.subtask: C-10.04 Tests DWV systems
questions.question: What documentation should accompany test results?

options.A: Date, test method, pressure/head, duration, results, and defects corrected

explanations.A: Complete test documentation provides code compliance proof and reference for future work or issues.
explanations.B: Comprehensive documentation is required for code compliance, warranty, and future reference needs.
explanations.C: Contractor identification is one component; complete technical test data must be documented.
explanations.D: Test documentation is mandatory for proving code compliance and providing records for warranty and future reference.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, tests and services interior drainage, waste and vent (DWV) systems
questions.subtask: C-10.05 Services DWV systems
questions.question: How can drain flies be eliminated from drainage systems?

options.A: Clean drains removing organic buildup where they breed

explanations.A: Drain flies breed in organic buildup in drains; thorough cleaning eliminates breeding sites and infestations.
explanations.B: Drain flies indicate unsanitary conditions and organic accumulation; they should be eliminated through proper cleaning.
explanations.C: Drain flies indicate drain maintenance needs; addressing the organic buildup they breed in is necessary.
explanations.D: Organic accumulation provides breeding sites; elimination requires removing buildup through proper drain cleaning.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, tests and services interior drainage, waste and vent (DWV) systems
questions.subtask: C-10.05 Services DWV systems
questions.question: What causes bubbling in fixtures when others are used?

options.A: Inadequate venting forcing air through trap seals when drainage occurs

explanations.A: Insufficient venting creates vacuum during drainage forcing air through nearby trap seals causing bubbling sounds.
explanations.B: Bubbling indicates venting problems; properly vented systems operate silently without trap disturbance.
explanations.C: Inadequate, not excessive, venting causes bubbling; proper venting prevents pressure problems.
explanations.D: Bubbling indicates venting deficiency requiring correction; it signals potential trap seal loss problems.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, tests and services interior drainage, waste and vent (DWV) systems
questions.subtask: C-10.05 Services DWV systems
questions.question: Why should enzyme or bacterial drain cleaners be preferred over chemical cleaners?

options.A: Enzymes biologically digest organic buildup without damaging pipes or environment

explanations.A: Biological cleaners safely digest organic matter without pipe damage or environmental harm unlike harsh chemicals.
explanations.B: Chemical cleaners can damage pipes and are environmental hazards; biological methods are safer alternatives.
explanations.C: Enzyme cleaners effectively digest organic buildup over time without chemical hazards or pipe damage.
explanations.D: Enzyme cleaners are much safer for pipes and environment than caustic chemical cleaners; they are preferable choices.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, tests and services interior drainage, waste and vent (DWV) systems
questions.subtask: C-10.05 Services DWV systems
questions.question: What indicates a clogged vent system?

options.A: Slow drainage throughout the system, gurgling sounds, and trap seal loss

explanations.A: Vent blockages prevent air circulation causing slow drainage, gurgling, and trap siphonage throughout affected areas.
explanations.B: Vent blockages cause widespread drainage problems; perfect operation indicates properly functioning vents.
explanations.C: Vent blockages slow drainage by restricting air flow; rapid drainage indicates proper venting.
explanations.D: Vents can be blocked by debris, ice, or nests requiring clearing to restore proper system function.

questions.taskTitle: Installs, tests and services interior drainage, waste and vent (DWV) systems
questions.subtask: C-10.05 Services DWV systems
questions.question: How should a backed-up floor drain be cleared?

options.A: Use plunger, snake, or professional equipment depending on blockage severity

explanations.A: Mechanical clearing methods are most effective; severity determines whether simple plunging or professional equipment is needed.
explanations.B: Chemicals alone may not clear complete blockages and can damage pipes; mechanical clearing is more effective.
explanations.C: Floor drain backups indicate blockages requiring clearing to restore function and prevent unsanitary conditions.
